name: Adina-Ioana VĂLEAN
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I am hooned to be here before you today to commemorate with you this important event for Romania and Europe at large. Thirty years ago, on December 16, 1989, the Romanian Revolution began in Timisoara. This was the first step towards the return of Romania and Romanians to Europe, after decades of enforced isolation based on artificial divisions between east and west. The Romanian revolution was the final act of the popular anti-communist movements in Central and Eastern Europe and the bloodiest: more than a thousand people paid the price of life in those days.  That winter in 1989, Romanians fought for freedom, fundamental rights, rule of law and democracy. These values form the foundation of our Europe as we know it today, beyond differences in language, race or tradition. They brought us together, from north to south, from east to west, and the perpetuation of these values, of fundamental rights, of the rule of law must continue to be an engine of European unity.  The violence with which the communist regime tried to suppress Romanians' aspirations for freedom and democracy, as well as the hardships of the transitional period, seem today to light years compared to 1989, for Romania - part of the European Union. I remember as a personal experience - I was 21 years old, I was in my last year of college at the time of the revolution - those days in December will remain forever in my soul and in the collective memory of the Romanian people. I then experienced the transition to democracy, years of transition that led or culminated in my country's accession to the European Union. We know, however, that nothing is perennial. We must ensure that no one else knows totalitarian regimes, shortages and isolation, and that is why we must look to the future and apply these principles, primarily in relation to the countries in the immediate vicinity.  There's still a way to go. Our journey to full convergence with the core of the European Union is in full swing. We continue to monitor the state of the rule of law...  But Romania is resourceful. The economy continues growing healthily, the country excels in developing skills, notably in new technologies and the digital economy. I am sure we will continue in the years to come. The recently-adopted European Green Deal has set an ambition to leave nobody behind. As Transport Commissioner, it will be my task to ensure our mobility systems, which are the foundation of our economy and our daily lives, the main accessible and provide development opportunities for all across Europe. In Romania, support for the EU stands at record levels, with 72% of Romanians saying nowadays they benefited from their country's membership of the EU and turned out for the last European elections in higher numbers than the EU average. In December 1989, as the blurred images of the revolution hit all news channels worldwide, Romania was back, and there isn't a better place than the European Parliament to celebrate the 30 years of the comeback of Romania and of the entire Central and Eastern Europe at the heart of the European family.

name: Traian BĂSESCU
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, first of all, thank you to my fellow MEPs, the parliamentary groups that have agreed that this debate should take place at the heart of European democracy.  Today we celebrate 30 years, exactly today, from the moment Timisoara erupted in a seemingly trivial incident, on December 16, 1989. On December 17, Ceaușescu's criminal regime was shooting at the people's army. The revolution spread from Timisoara to all the cities of the country. Millions of Romanians were in the streets.  The brutality of the regime was materialized in more than 1,142 Romanians shot, 3,200 Romanians wounded, 700 Romanians tortured. However, any of the millions of Romanians who took to the streets were in front of the bullets of the Romanian Army turned against their own people.  The Romanians' desire to return to a Europe of values, where they were taken away with Soviet tanks, was much stronger than the fear of repression. It is a time when Romanians said "no" resolutely, with the sacrifice of their lives, communism and returned to the European family. Today I'm in NATO, I'm in Europe, I'm where they belong. I would conclude by saying that the European Union is not only about peace in Europe, the European Union is also about the prohibition of dictatorships within the European Union.

name: Cristian TERHEŞ
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the Revolution of December 1989 ended a totalitarian, criminal and odious communist regime in Romania. Unlike other former communist countries, the return from communism to democracy in Romania was made through human sacrifice.  More than a thousand people died for freedom and thousands more were injured. The thousands of human sacrifices of December 1989 are added to the hundreds of thousands of Romanians of all ethnicities and denominations in Romania, who since the establishment of communism in Romania in 1946 fought and campaigned for the defence of freedom, democracy and fundamental human rights.  Many of them fought with guns in their hands as partisans in the mountains, others were jailed by the Communists and died in unsanitary prisons, while others took the path of exile. Thousands more Romanians were shot at the Romanian border when they tried to escape westward from the great prison where the Communists transformed Romania.  Because it refused to institutionally serve the Communist Party, the Greek Catholic Church in Romania was outlawed in 1948, and its bishops, along with hundreds of priests and thousands of believers, were thrown into the prison, where many died.  Along with Greek Catholic priests, Orthodox priests, Protestant and neo-Protestant pastors, even people without a particular confession and different ethnicities, were placed in communist prisons because they refused to serve the Communist Party or opposed communist ideology. They are joined by millions of Romanian families to whom the Communist State confiscated their land and any other property they had, destroying their sources of subsistence. The 1989 revolution in Romania was the culmination of the struggle to restore freedom and democracy in Romania, which had been going on for over 40 years. Thirty years after the anti-communist revolution, we commemorate this event and are pleased that all The representatives of Romania in this House are turning their hands forward to carry on the freedom for them and for the generations that will come after us.

name: Dacian CIOLOŞ
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Madam President, exactly 30 years ago, on 16 December 1989, in Timisoara, the spark of the Romanian Revolution was lit. A few hundred people then dared to oppose the totalitarian regime. They were joined in the hours and days that followed hundreds, then thousands, of people and the revolution spread to Bucharest, Brasov, Cluj, Arad and the whole country.  In Timisoara, the first shots were fired. Those people had no illusions that they would be forgiven by the regime, they knew they were risking their lives, and yet they took to the streets, chose freedom, had the courage to denounce dictatorship, oppression, lack of freedom, economic deprivation, in one of the toughest communist regimes in the world. Today, in the European Parliament, we pay tribute to the courage of these people. Their courage is what made it possible for Romania to return to the values of democracy, pluralism, the rule of law, freedom. It is what has brought us back to the map of free, democratic and united Europe.  In those days, ordinary people became heroes. Many, too many of them never came home alive. A mother recounted how on December 22, after sit in the street for a day and a night in Bucharest, her son returned home with his shirt covered in blood because a friend of his had been protesting with had died in his arms. The man left for work on the 22nd afternoon and the mother found him on the 26th, coming home in the coffin.  Children who, after 30 years, are now the age of the parents they lost then. Last year, when the names of the heroes were flown on the fence of the Royal Palace, in Bucharest's Revolution Square, such a child, who was already an adult, came and wrote, along with his father's name, "I love you, Daddy".  Those children ask themselves day by day what is the meaning of their parents' sacrifice. And they, first of all, but also others have the right to know the truth about what happened then, and we must fight so that people never go out on the streets and die for their freedom, neither now nor in future generations.

text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, today we are celebrating the last act of that extraordinary season of people and freedom that we experienced in Europe in 1989.  Let us celebrate the courage of thousands of men and women in Romania who sacrificed their lives so that their children could live in a nation finally free from Communist oppression.  And for this reason I want to quote the words of a great Romanian Christian intellectual and artist, Camilian Demetrescu: "We were resigned to living forever outside our land in this West that could not or did not want to understand that communist utopia was already condemned by history, all that remained was the disconcerting hypothesis of the miracle. That's why, in those days all over the country, candles lit on the windows." Finally, so that it is not just rhetorical, so that the values sprouted by the Romanian Revolution continue to flourish in the world, I would like to address a thought to the young people of Hong Kong, who are being persecuted today by the Chinese Communist regime in the disinterest of the world. name: Siegfried MUREŞAN
text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, on 16 December 1989, exactly 30 years ago, thousands of Romanians took to the streets for the first time, and hundreds of thousands of Romanians followed them in the following days. These events known as the "Romanian Revolution" led to the elimination of communism in Romania and led to the return of Romania and the Romanian people to Europe.  Through the Romanian Revolution, the doors were opened for millions of Romanians, to say what they were thinking, and gained their freedom of expression, to read what they wanted, to see, for the first time, their relatives, family members who had gone abroad and which perhaps some of them could not see at all until then. Romania and the Romanian people earned their place in Europe through those sacrifices in the days of the Romanian Revolution. The key word, Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, of today's debate must be 'commemoration'. Today we need to think, more than ever, about the 1,142 Romanians who lost their lives in the days of the Romanian Revolution. While, in other European countries, the communist regime could be peacefully removed, in our country, in Romania, this required the sacrifice of the lives of 1,142 people, many of whom were young. They fought for democracy, for freedom, for freedom of expression, and today we have to think about them. Over the last 30 years, Romanians have always continued this struggle. They fought for European values and to regain Romania's place in the European Union. Madam President, I believe that all of us, all 751 Members of the European Parliament from all 28 Member States of the European Union, have a duty to defend the values for which Romanians lost their lives in December 1989 - democracy, freedom, freedom of expression, justice - and to continue to make every effort to continue the process of European integration and for the peaceful coexistence of all nations within the European Union.

name: Adrian-Dragoş BENEA
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, honourable Members, in the winter of 1989 in Romania, the man Gheorghe Dorel Nechita had his whole life ahead of him. His family was preparing his marriage, scheduled for the following year, 1990. On a certain Tuesday, December 22, a stray bullet pierced the heart of the brave George, as his family called him, killing him instantly.  For the young researcher at the Institute of Atomic Physics, it all ended before it started, at just 29 years old. George would never come home to his family again, in Bacau, which he had in his heart pierced by the killer bullet. Today he sleeps his final sleep in the cemetery of his hometown of Bacau, and every year, on 22 December, his mother seeks an answer to a question that has troubled the days and nights of the last 30 years: "Who killed my boy?"  The blood sacrifice of the more than 5,200 victims of the Revolution, of whom more than 1,100 died, demands just judgment. The heroes of the Revolution paved the way for democracy and the rule of law in Romania. Therefore, beyond constantly honoring their memory, we must do everything within our remit to find out the truth and elucidate the crimes. Those responsible must respond. It's never too late for such a desire.

name: Vlad-Marius BOTOŞ
text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, this month marks the 30th anniversary of the 1989 Revolution in Romania. It was the only country where the communist regime fought to remain in power, despite clear opposition from the Romanians. More than a thousand people perished, several thousand were injured in the nearly ten days of unrest and confrontation between the police and law enforcement. A large part of these victims were from Timisoara, the city where the Revolution began, exactly 30 years ago. It is, and now, incredibly, their courage to stand up to the communist regime, knowing that they could be alone, and yet they could not conceive that the authorities would shoot unarmed people, women, children. The tragedy was that they started shooting. Even so, the Timisorians resisted. It may seem too dramatic to say that they remained in the street under the fire of bullets, and this is the clearest picture you can have when you think of the Romanian Revolution of 1989.  The people who stood there, in the square, in the streets, saw their friends fall next to them and they could choose to leave, to save themselves, but they didn't. Arad, my city, the second city to join the Revolution, had its share of struggle, death and wounded. We remember them today, after 30 years, and we pay tribute to them, as they deserve.  The 1989 revolution is that moment in our history that shows us the strength that people have when they fight together for principles. In Timişoara, in Arad, in Bucharest, in all the other cities where people took to the streets, this "together" gave them the power to bring down the mountain of totalitarianism.  Our gratitude is not enough. Our tribute is not enough. We must demand, as we have been doing for 30 years, the truth. We must demand justice for themselves and for all those who risked their lives in those days, for the families of the victims. It is time for the Romanian State to deal with this dark chapter in Romania's life with celere and, however much it may hurt, to present us with the truth. We need to know who the main culprits are for the 1989 slaughter for our heroes to rest in peace.

The revolution that began with Timisoara, which moved the whole of Romania as one, tore down communism and created freedom in Romania. Although the crimes against humanity committed in the revolution remained untenable, they have remained unpunished to this day. In the Romanian Revolution, we also remember the more than 1,200 victims killed by the Communist armies today. This revolution, the Romanian Revolution, is one of those moments in history in which the peoples of Europe were able to fight together for freedom and rejoice together. name: Dan-Ştefan MOTREANU
text: – Madam President, this year marks the 30th anniversary of the Romanian Revolution, the first televised revolution in history and millions of people in the country, in Europe, and not only have they seen very clearly the violence against citizens who wanted to oust a totalitarian regime.  This is why what happened in December 1989 in Romania was not only a feeling of Romanians, but also of Europeans who showed, and at that time, their solidarity and attachment to the Romanian people and, obviously, like the Romanians, waited to find out the truth about these events.  But since then it has been three decades and year after year the Romanian people are waiting for an answer on what happened in December 1989. They are waiting for an end in which all the culprits are tried and convicted according to the facts, complicities and culpability of each of them. There is still, in Romanian society, a fear that this expectation can continue as long as no one and nothing will succeed in pushing justice in Romania to establish the truth and until then the main actors or witnesses will physically disappear and even the descendants and close to the fallen, and this file will remain in a drawer with the resolution "unknown author". Because yes, the truth is clear and simple described in the Revolution file, it says exactly who and how it acted, at whose behest it acted, knowing, in many cases, the perpetrator of each crime. Colleagues, Romania also needs the truth. Romania cannot heal and even completely detach itself from the past as long as the culprits of December 1989 are not officially known. Sooner or later, the truth always comes out, but sometimes it's too late. This time, we don't want it to be too late again. This is the aim of this resolution in the European Parliament, that December 1989 should not become a moment of oblivion, but a moment of memory, of freedom, and for this we need truth as soon and forever as possible. I also said in my intervention that Romania suffered greatly because those culprits have not been discovered since the early 1990s and some of those who made a bad contribution to this revolution have been perpetuated in public office in Romania.

name: Carmen AVRAM
text: – Madam President, personally, as a man who has lived half his life in an opresive regime, I believe that there is nothing more dangerous and humiliating for a human being than dictatorship. I also believe that the distance between democracy and dictatorship is sometimes separated by only a fraction of a second, that fraction of a second in which you choose to shut up instead of talk. The victims of the Revolution were killed by bullets, but in fact, their tragic destiny was decided by the criminal silence of those who worked for or indulged in the system of their own silence and benefits. It is good that the truth of 1989 is known. In addition, however, it is our obligation to be careful and to speak loudly, firmly, in time, so that we can save those people we would otherwise pay homage to post mortem. Let us all pay attention to the first signs of dictatorship, because today it is much more subtle, sometimes hiding right behind a democratic appearance and being able to pervert by manipulation even enlightened minds.  A form of dictatorship begins to build itself when you discover that you can no longer assert your political option without being verbally assaulted and isolated, including by the circle of friends or family, or when your country is ideologically divided into two camps willing to tear apart until there is only one left. The truth is therefore important, but we also need to see the signs and in that decisive fraction of a second we choose to speak.

name: Loránt VINCZE
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, 30 years ago, as communist regimes collapsed throughout Europe and democratic reforms swept through out eastern Europe, dictator Nicolae Ceaușescu seemed adamant, but the evacuation by the police on 15 December of the reformed Hungarian pastor László Tőkés gave the spark of a savage fire that engulfed the whole country in a few days. His determination to publicly denounce human rights violations and to oppose the plan to systematize the villages preceded the outbreak of the Revolution.  Although his subsequent political work raises many questions, the withdrawal of the distinction for the merits of Mr Tőkés, a former Member of this Parliament, is a huge injustice. No temporal authority can remove its status as a symbol of the Revolution or diminish its collective gratitude. Colleagues, much remains to be done in the Revolution file. It is extremely sad that no Romanian, apart from the Ceaușescus, was found guilty of supporting communist terror. Unfortunately, Romania has not adopted a lustre law. Former collaborators have access to central government positions. In an abusive way, the restitution of property seized by the communist regime has dragged on for years.  Out of respect for the more than a thousand people who lost their lives during the Revolution and the communist regime, 30 years after the Revolution, not a moment should be lost to hold the guilty accountable and to repair the crimes and damage caused by the communist regime. In order for today to live in a healthy society, we must have the courage to face our own past.

name: Tudor CIUHODARU
text: – Madam President, today we are talking about the homage of Romania, about the courage of the Romanian people and of my country to oppose a draconian dictatorial regime, to fight fear, hunger and cold, under conditions that others could not have imagined. Let us not forget to say that, on 14 December, that manifesto to all Romanians of good faith in Iaşi opened the spark to this revolution and that if it had not been for the brutal intervention of the Militia and Security, a different situation would have been reached.  I'm telling you today that my daughter is the age of the Revolution. I told him about those days, he grew up watching and seeing as we enter the European Union and NATO, and in order for these European values to continue, we have an obligation, as we have done today, to make the other walls fall further.  So today, if we still bring the honor of this Revolution, I ask you to pay tribute to Romania, to pay tribute to all of us by making the things important to us come true. So today, again, after 30 years, Your Honor, I remind you that we fulfil all the conditions and ask you to enter Schengen.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I come from Timisoara. Exactly 30 years ago, I was on the street in Timişoara with the citizens of Timişoara and for the truth, please understand that the Revolution is not of a person or a group of people. The revolution is of the Romanians, of the Timisoaras who lit the flame and who carried this flame, as they shouted "Today in Timisoara, tomorrow all over the country!"  This is the truth about the Revolution: it was a popular uprising, people came out of factories, from all factories, from all corners of Timişoara. We started calling in other cities: "Get out on the street!", because it was not yet known, in Bucharest, what is in Timişoara. Allow me, that it is a commemoration, to bow to the thousands of dead, to the Timisorians, who sacrificed themselves first, in front of the Romanians who came out without weapons, with open arms in front of those who came to shoot them, simply to shoot them.  I believe that we have a duty, dear colleagues and the European institutions, to respect the Romanian people. The Romanian people are pro-European. Do not follow information and certain leaders. The Romanian people are pro-European. Our place is in the European Union and out of respect, now, at 30 years old, I ask you, the Commission, the Council, Parliament, to respect the rights of Romanians, European citizens. Give us credibility because yes, in 30 years, Romania has changed a lot. You may not know how much, but we invite you home to us and dear Romanians, wherever you live, ask for unity, solidarity and love your country.

name: Eugen TOMAC
text: – Madam President, 30 years ago, millions of Romanians faced fear, took to the streets to demand that Romania permanently break away from a criminal regime; millions of Romanians against whom more than 12 million bullets were fired shouted in the street "Freedom, we love you! Either we win or we die."  These innocent voices expressed a state of desire for freedom for what Romania was about to achieve: democracy and an irreversible path on the path of European integration. Romania, at that time, broke for good from a harsh period in which hundreds of thousands of people died in communist prisons, and today, because of this sacrifice - and thank you for paying tribute to these heroes in the plenary of the European Parliament. Heroes never die and I bow to them. Thank you for this unique and important moment for my nation.

name: Robert HAJŠEL
text: – Madam President, indeed, 30 years ago, a great popular uprising broke out in Romania, and romanians also got rid of the dictatorship, got rid of the totalitarian communist regime of Comrade Ceausesco. It has to be said that since then Romania has come a long way, it has not been easy, Romania has lost its population and it is still a long way off, as are our countries, the Czech Republic or Slovakia, in terms of standard of living compared to Germany, for example.  In a democracy, of course, we have weaknesses in building democracy, and we have weaknesses in other areas as well. However, we must also work together with the European Union to address these weaknesses, including with the instruments we have here, to build and strengthen the rule of law, and therefore also to use all legislative instruments to assess and properly and fairly assess the human rights situation, respect for the rule of law and respect for minority rights in all countries equally because we have bugs everywhere, some make more of them, some less.

name: Clare DALY
text: – Madam President, I was a student leader in Ireland 30 years ago and, inspired by the heroism of Romanian students and workers, I travelled to Bucharest and Timișoara and spent over a month there in the midst of those revolutionary days. I have to say that it was one of the most defining experiences of my youth to witness the overthrow of Ceaușescu’s brutal totalitarian regime, an elite which enriched themselves at the expense of the population and developed a vicious secret police and state apparatus to do so. It was an absolutely incredible experience. To feel the hopes of the population for the future, for democracy, for a say in their lives and for a more stable economic experience was very humbling.  But we have to be honest as well, because what did they get? In many ways they got much of the same elite in new clothes, combined also with a new elite – a new neoliberal elite – and many people have unresolved issues there. We have to ask why Romania has got the second biggest diaspora in the world, second only to Syria – five million driven out of that country. There is a lot of corruption still to tackle. So I stand continually in solidarity with those people. The revolution has not been completed there.

name: Iuliu WINKLER
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support Romania's anti-communist revolution began in Timisoara. When, on 15 December, people, Hungarians and Romanians from Timisoara gathered outside the Reformed Church to defend pastor László Tőkés and his family members, who the Communist authorities wanted to forcibly evict. On those bloody Days of December, human solidarity has taken on a depth that has not been repeated in Romania since. Today, using the political weapons of democracy, we are committed to fighting for a rule of law in which all citizens and all communities enjoy equal rights and equal protection. The RMDSZ strongly advocates, in Strasbourg and Bucharest, that the objectives set out 30 years ago must be fully achieved. To do this, we need society to know the truth about the events of December 1989 and for the judiciary to hold accountable those responsible for the deaths of innocent people.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Sorry, Madam President, I can see a colleague here waving a blue card. Do you want to address this before I speak?

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: No, we will not allow a blue card during catch-the-eye. The floor is yours.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Madam President, I represent the North West of England, where there is a large Romanian population with whom I work very closely, and I’m happy to call many of them my friends. They are doctors, nurses, teachers, artists, entrepreneurs. Many of them remember the Romanian revolution and the cruel dictatorship that preceded it. Now, not only are Romanians free in their own country, but since 2007 they have also enjoyed the benefits of the EU membership. However, Brexit presents a frightening prospect for the Romanian diaspora in the UK, who are increasingly on the receiving end of often violent racist abuse. Indeed, over night of 23 June 2016, a group of Romanian children who regularly played out on the streets in Manchester were called indoors by their parents, who were worried for their safety in the increasingly hostile environment. To my knowledge, those children are still deprived of the freedom to play out with other children. It’s a sad indictment of Brexit Britain that people who suffered under totalitarianism now feel anxious and unwelcome in their adopted home.

name: Adina-Ioana VĂLEAN
text: Member of the Commission. – Thank you very much, Madam President. There’s not much more to say for me at this stage, but to thank those who brought the topic to the debate. Those who supported and participated in the debate. I wish the House good luck with the resolution on Thursday and I take it that for the Romanians, for those like you and like myself, working in Europe, for the good of all people, there is a huge responsibility lying in the future. Because we are bearing with us the hopes of those people back in 1989 hoping for a better life and a better Europe.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, 19 December 2019. Written statements (Rule 171)

name: Sandra KALNIETE
text: in writing. – Thirty years ago, a violent uprising in Romania ended the communist regime of Ceaușescu and opened up the country’s path towards the EU, NATO and the democratic world. Years of shortages, food and fuel rationing, power cuts and stifling surveillance had driven Romanians to breaking point. This was the most violent of all the uprisings leading to the fall of communism in the states behind the Iron Curtain. Romania had the only revolution that saw the perpetrator sentenced to death and executed, but there are still many questions that remain unanswered. Last month, a Bucharest court opened preliminary hearings into allegations that Iliescu and two associates committed crimes against humanity in December 1989, leading to the deaths of 862 people and injury to 2 150 after Ceaușescu fled. There were 700 hundred people queuing for hours to attend the hearing. That queue is the best proof that Romanians still want justice. I call on Romania to boost its efforts to clarify the truth of the past, to do its utmost to ensure the crimes of communist regimes are remembered and guarantee such crimes will never be committed again. It is an absolute necessity for the country, the Romanian people, and the EU.

name: Mihai TUDOSE
text: in writing. – 30 years after the Romanian Revolution, the European Parliament pays tribute to the most dramatic of the communist regime overthrows of 1989. At the foundation of the freedom regained by the Romanians lies the blood sacrifice of the 1,116 dead and 4,089 wounded, many in still unclear circumstances. Knowing the truth about the events of December '89 is a pressing moral and legal obligation. It is also essential to understand the tragic meanings of history so close, especially because we are at a crossroads for the European project.  Three decades ago, the Romanians freed themselves by sacrifice from the dictatorship imposed by the Soviet occupation and accepted by The Western states. If the east-west fracture persists within the EU, then it is also because of the failure to assume this historical responsibility. In the face of revisionist aggression in the immediate neighbourhood and populist-nationalist slippages that undermine European unity, we have only one chance: the solidarity of EU states, in the name of the attachment of citizens to freedom and democracy.  Effective European solidarity requires a double effort: to overcome the cleavages maintained by selfish ambitions and to reduce the development gaps inherited from an unjust history. The old Member States have a duty to do so. So let's not waste it!

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: The next item is the joint debate on – the report by Lídia Pereira, on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, on the proposal for a Council directive amending Directive 2006/112/EC as regards introducing certain requirements for payment service providers (COM(2018)0812 – C8-0015/2019 – 2018/0412(CNS)) (A9—0048/2019), and – the report by Lídia Pereira, on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, on the proposal for a Council regulation amending Regulation (EU) No 904/2010 as regards measures to strengthen administrative cooperation in order to combat VAT fraud (COM(2018)0813 – C8-0016/2019 – 2018/0413(CNS)) (A9-0047/2019). I remind you that it is possible to request catch-the-eye and blue cards using both the standard registration and the electronic system. Instructions are available at the entrance of the Hemicycle.

name: Lídia PEREIRA
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the digitisation of our societies and economies creates opportunities for all, citizens and businesses, new products and better services, solutions for the second, but they also open the door to more sophisticated forms of law and tax evasion. We must anticipate the problems of the future and decide in the present with the speed and intelligence that this era of innovation requires. VAT is an important source of tax revenue for all Member States and for the Union, which has its own source of revenue here. Harmonising rules and bringing tax policies closer to VAT is to protect the integrity of the internal market and a free movement of goods and services based on fair tax rules. Combating fraud and tax evasion is a priority to strengthen citizens' confidence in democratic institutions and public administrations across Europe. VAT is based on communication by operators of a given value chain and therefore based on trust. While it is true that the overwhelming majority of these agents are reliable and fulfil their obligations, unfortunately VAT fraud remains a problem. The difference between the VAT estimated to be collected and the vat actually collected in 2017 was EUR 137.5 billion. And this means a loss of EUR 267 for every European citizen. VAT fraud in e-commerce in the Union represents EUR 5 billion annually, equivalent to the product of all e-commerce of the Portuguese in a year. The reports we are discussing today are the manifestation of this Parliament's willingness to go further in combating this fraud that harms us all. At the same time, we have created a central European system for the collection and exchange of payment data and we have strengthened the obligations of payment services to collect, retain and communicate such data. With our amendments we want to signal our willingness to put more ambition and affirm this Parliament's commitment to a more effective fight against VAT fraud. Let me therefore highlight a few key aspects: The increased retention period ensures that authorities have more time to identify possible fraud. Determining a minimum amount, which activates the payment service's reporting obligation in a single transaction, reduces the space to bypass the system we are approving. With the express reference to the obligations before the European Data Protection Supervisor we point out that no due diligence of public authorities or payment services violates the fundamental right of Europeans to the privacy and protection of their personal data. Advocating the use of new technologies in payment systems, we call for modernisation and stress the need to simplify procedures for businesses and citizens. Ladies and gentlemen, what we are talking about here today is truly justice, it is to ensure that everyone, regardless of country or their digital skills, pays their share. Financial technology is changing every day the way we consume, negotiate and pay for the services we hire. And we need to adapt our legislation to the new realities of the digital world. VAT fraud knows no borders and can only be combated with increasing cooperation between national authorities and European institutions. It is in our hands to ensure greater fairness, ensuring fairer and flawless taxation, levelling the conditions in a fight, even today unequal, between those who seek to evade their obligations and those who defend tax justice.

name: Lídia PEREIRA
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I am very proud to stand in front of this assembly for the first time as the Commissioner for economy. I look forward to the important work ahead of us, and the fight against tax fraud is high on our respective agendas. I would like to thank the rapporteur, Lídia Pereira, and the members of Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs (ECON) for their excellent work on the two proposals we are discussing.  VAT fraud is a major issue affecting all Member States and citizens alike, and it is important that measures aimed at attacking VAT fraud can be subject to a democratic debate in this plenary. The present proposal should be examined in line with the VAT and e—commerce package that was adopted by the Council in December 2017, and will enter into application in January 2021. The proposal provides tax authorities with a powerful tool that will allow them to detect and fight VAT fraud in the e-commerce sector. European action is absolutely necessary.  In 2015, as the rapporteur remembers, EUR 5 billion of VAT was lost in the European Union solely on imports of goods. Similar numbers have been reported with regard to supplies of services. This problem is also likely to keep growing in future, considering the growth rate of e-commerce in Europe.  The Commission has proposed to create an obligation for payment service providers established in the Union to transmit data on the beneficiary of cross-border payments they execute. This obligation was designed to limit administrative burdens in that regard. The requested information is already available and used by payment service providers to process transactions. Although this proposal constitutes a big step forward in the fight against VAT fraud, there is still much to do. This year’s Commission study on the VAT gap shows that the Member States were in general losing EUR 137 billion in 2017, and these numbers are obviously still too high.  Because of this, I intend to make the fight against tax fraud a top priority of my mandate. Of course the fight against tax fraud goes hand in hand with improving tax compliance. This is why these two aspects will be part of a new action plan I will present next year. EU business must be able to access the EU market without constraints and unfair competition by those that are not compliant. EU citizens must be able to legally access the worldwide market and benefit from the redistribution of the revenue collected.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, Commissioner, rapporteur, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. Every year, we deplore a VAT gap of EUR 137.5 billion, which is 11.2% of expected VAT receipts, cross-border VAT fraud of over EUR 50 billion and growing tax fraud in online commerce, where more than 90% of transactions are carried out through payment service providers.  I am therefore very pleased, firstly, about the announcements, Commissioner, from you about the action plan, but also about the two reports by my colleague, Mrs Pereira, because with both reports we are taking a very important step towards the creation of a single European VAT area and these measures are the new VAT regime for e-commerce, which is due to enter into force in January 2021. Complement.  We urgently need a system of common rules, rather than a system of exceptions and loopholes. We must put a stop to VAT fraudsters and stop the unacceptable theft of taxpayers' money. That is why I am also saying to the Council, despite the positive decisions taken on 8 November, that anyone who blocks more European and common European tax policy supports the fraudsters and supports waste. We must therefore combat this instrument of unanimity. We need greater cooperation between tax authorities and payment service providers, harmonised requirements for payment service providers for cross-border payments, access to information by anti-fraud agencies and a new centralised electronic system for storing payment information.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support One of the most important tasks of the European Union is to ensure social justice and a life worthy of man for all citizens of the Union. Fair taxation is an essential condition for this. The fight against cross-border tax fraud is therefore one of the most important tasks of the European Union, and therefore for us Members of Parliament. We cannot continue to avoid taxation across Europe because of all sorts of loopholes, a lack of cooperation between Member States or cynicism and cynical collation of some Member States. As a Hungarian MEMBER, I come from a country with the highest VAT rate in the entire European Union and even the whole world: 27 percent. This also means that my country is one of the favourite destinations and hunting grounds for VAT fraudsters. As a Hungarian, I know exactly what it is like when public money migrates to fraudsters. Tax evasion is not the prank of some international craftsman, as it causes €137 billion in damage across Europe. Tax evasion is therefore a crime that seriously threatens the functioning of education, health, social care and public services in general, undermines social justice, our common Europe without borders and, of course, destroys European democracy and risks the peace of everyday life. It is therefore very important that we were able to prepare the drafts on cross-border VAT fraud together and put them on Parliament's table. As we promised, together with you, we have worked together to make sure that these taxes are not only paid by those living on wages, by family businesses, but also by achieving that no one can cheat or arreat their privileged position. These proposals strengthen cooperation and exchange of information between Member States, ensure the long-term recording of data and thus ensure effective action against cross-border tax fraud. I therefore ask you to vote in favour of this, all proposals deserve to become law.

name: Ondřej KOVAŘÍK
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Madam President, first I would like to welcome the Commissioner’s commitment that he has just articulated to make VAT and tax fraud in general his priority.  Commissioner, I think you would also have huge support in this House. You mentioned that the numbers of the value added tax gap are slowly and gradually decreasing but, according to the Commission estimates and indications, it should still be around EUR 130 billion in 2018 and that is indeed still quite a high number. As was also mentioned by other colleagues, the VAT carousel frauds, whereby criminals abuse the EU cross—border trading system, contribute EUR 50 billion on average per year in lost revenue for Member States’ tax authorities. The legislation we are debating here today will help drastically reduce the revenues lost to VAT fraud in our financial systems. Their losses are damaging not only to the governments. They are also felt throughout the economic chain and therefore damage the vast majority of legitimate businesses, particularly small and medium-sized companies in the European Union. I therefore fully support the efforts to address the deficiencies in VAT regimes in Europe. From the European Parliament perspective, we have emphasised the importance of legislation being appropriate for the modern age. This is something we will need to monitor on a continuous basis to ensure that our rules are fit for purpose and achieve the goal of increasing the efficiency of VAT collection and combating fraud. We must not forget the time and money it takes, especially for smaller companies, to collect and report their appropriate VAT information to authorities. Therefore, for our group it is important that the new rules do not add an undue administrative burden which may hamper the efforts of smaller businesses to grow, particularly across borders within the single market. European legislation in this area needs to be future-oriented with a clear focus on ensuring it can be applied as business models evolve in the coming years. I therefore appreciate that the Parliament has specifically pointed to the digital arena in this report as our commercial environment becomes ever more digital. I would also encourage VAT authorities to consider the development of artificial-intelligence-based solutions to tackle fraud. Specifically, artificial intelligence could be used to create a risk model that would help identify anomalies in the system. In this way, the AI could minimise hours spent  by officials in compiling such information. By increasing efficiency, we can target carousel frauds in particular in a more effective manner.  Let me conclude by thanking the rapporteur and colleagues for their cooperation on these two files. We have drafted two reports that reflect Parliament’s priorities, particularly as regards the administrative cooperation and payment service providers. I believe that these are the right steps needed in the area of tax collection, which enhance cross-border cooperation on the one hand and help fight tax fraud on the other.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, these measures were urgently needed, because online VAT fraud is currently costing the EU 5 billion euros a year. Online shopping is on the rise; this is something that will get even bigger and that we need to address. We want to highlight the cooperation between tax administrations. This is really important when we have an internal market like the EU with many cross-border transactions. Tax administrations need to be properly staffed to be able to fight tax evasion, and unfortunately this is not always the case. This reform is part of a series of VAT reforms to improve our VAT rules in the European Union. But one very important issue that is not covered by this reform, but which the EU needs to look into urgently, is the exemption of VAT for the aviation sector. It is not coherent to exempt the aviation sector from VAT when other sectors are subject to it, especially when the Commission presents a Green Deal and needs to make all its legislation aligned with the commitments taken during the COP21 in Paris.

name: Gunnar BECK
text: On behalf of the ID Group, I would like to make a i-see of the Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for his work and for the work she has VAT fraud is indeed a problem, but the Commission is only presenting us with sham solutions and a formula for more monitoring and tax maximisation. According to the Commission, €135 billion less than expected VAT revenues would cost each citizen €267 a year. Let's read correctly: the citizen? I think it is more the Commission and the Member States who are talking about it. The EU has the highest consumption taxes in the world. On average, EU citizens pay more than twice as much as others elsewhere. Compared to Japan or Canada, we pay three to four times. The EU is also at the forefront of personal taxes and social security contributions. Nowhere does the state have its hands as deep in as many pockets as in Europe. One should therefore expect an all-round luxury care for citizens from the cradle to the grave – the best kindergartens, schools, universities and hospitals and the highest pensions. Indeed, pensions are falling, real wages are stagnating, debt is rising, and the economy is stagnating. Why? The EU and governments should finally be honest: they need more and more money to live out their multicultural LBGT and world-saving fantasies. That is why the EU wants to undermine the principle of unanimity on taxes and calls for more supervision and more powerful prosecutors. The EU wants new and higher taxes and less democracy, but citizens want the opposite.

name: Eugen JURZYCA
text: for the ECR Group. – Madam President, VAT fraud is undoubtedly one of the biggest frauds in the European Union. According to the Commission's estimate, this is EUR 137 billion per year. A huge, astronomical number, and it is not only that they are missing out on health care, in education, but also that taxes must then be paid more by those who are the most respected. It is therefore good that the Union is acting, but it is not entirely true that this is a Europe-wide problem. If we look at the graph, this graph, we see a tax gap in the collection of VAT in the various Member States. While at the best end the VAT tax gap in Luxembourg or Cyprus is not even 1%, at the worst end of the list it is well above 30%, that is fifty times. I would therefore like to call on the Commission to carry out analyses in such situations, quality analyses on the basis of objective data. These would allow us to make decisions as we should, i.e. on the basis of facts and not just opinions or emotions, and then spread the best practices to other countries.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, Mr Gentiloni, we welcome you to the European Parliament, since it is your first presence here, but, because we are talking about large-scale tax fraud and tax evasion, what the European Parliament is asking the Commission to do is speed up efficiency to reduce this widespread tax fraud. The figures are frightening, very large, 137 billion a year for the European Union. This tax fraud is loaded on the backs of consistent and honest taxpayers, leads to cuts in the social state and also violates fair competition between businesses because fraudsters are favoured and consistent are punished. To address this, greater European cooperation, more effective control mechanisms, heavier penalties for offenders are needed. More and better Europe is needed and, in order to do this, laws and regulations and money are needed. I would also like to cautery the absence of the Council. Because Parliament is asking for things, the Commission is promising them, but the Council is absent and, moreover, the Finnish Presidency in its recent proposal for the new multiannual budget proposes to cut the funds for the cooperation programme to tackle tax fraud by 40% compared to what Parliament proposes and by 20% compared to what we had in the previous financial framework. So we're making fun of each other! Words are not enough, they need works and results.

name: Henrik OVERGAARD NIELSEN
text: – Madam President, any decision about VAT will affect any free trade agreement agreed between the EU and the UK.  On Thursday, the people of the UK voted resoundingly for Brexit and they voted overwhelmingly in favour of a Canada-style free trade agreement with the EU. They also voted emphatically against the customs union, against staying in the single market and against the European Court of Justice having any jurisdiction in the UK.  Everybody agreed that this election was a Brexit election, so the will of the people has been heard for the second time, may I say, on the issue of Brexit.  And the people have yet again told us that they knew what they voted for in 2016. This general election has proven that, when given the choice, the British people choose free trade and cooperation and not a political super-state. Will the remaining EU citizens ever be given this choice or will they drift further and further into the Federal States of Europe? The citizens of Europe should be given the choice and if they choose, like the Brits, we should roll back federalism and start co-operating again like nation states. It is called democracy.  It might seem strange to many of you, but not everyone subscribes to a centralised monolithic form of politics. Some of us actually believe in democracy. To quote Rabbi Sacks, ‘every one of us counts, every one of us has a voice’. You lose that, you lose everything, because then it becomes a game for the rich and powerful.  (Applause)

name: Pablo ARIAS ECHEVERRÍA
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, madam rapporteur, all Member States share the problem of tax evasion in transactions through e-commerce in the European Union. Vat collection losses are estimated for cross-border transactions of around EUR 5 billion. VAT fraud has also been found in the provision of services, although this is undoubtedly more difficult to quantify.  Member States alone do not have the information necessary to ensure the correct and effective application of VAT rules. Data exchange is not always possible because of legal limitations, which makes administrative cooperation inefficient in combating tax fraud in e-commerce. We need new tools to combat fraud in cross-border transactions in e-commerce. Information sharing, agility in decision-making and simplification of the norm are crucial to combating fraud effectively. For this reason, we support the proposal to create a central electronic payment storage system, and the obligation on the part of Member States to collect and transmit information from payment service providers. For this, it is necessary to simplify, it is necessary to harmonize the data collection process and its format. In this way, we will be more effective and may prevent payment providers from being required to submit the same information in different format in each Member State. This will undoubtedly be an effective tool for the fight against fraud and will be an efficient action that will allow payment service providers to save time and resources, removing barriers to further implementing a true digital single market.  Mrs. Pereira, congratulations on this good work. We've got to keep moving forward.

name: Marek BELKA
text: – Madam President, we are talking about the tax that is a major revenue source for Member States. Therefore, the fight against VAT fraud and VAT losses is to strive to minimise the impact on state budgets. It is a fight for our governments to finance hospitals, schools or invest in a safe infrastructure. According to statistics, the VAT gap in 2017 amounted to over 137 billion euros; that means more than around 260 euros per EU citizen were lost. While the differences across Member States vary, a unilateral fight to fight tax fraud is not efficient – only a common set of actions can solve or minimise the problem. Hence, I welcome the Commission’s proposals on the files we are discussing: introducing requirements for payment service providers, and strengthening cooperation within the EU in order to combat VAT fraud. At the same time, I want to stress two issues. The Commission should evaluate if virtual currency platforms should also be covered by the legislation. Also, in order to have more precise data on the VAT gap, I call on the Commission to develop a common statistical approach to quantify this phenomenon.

name: Bogdan RZOŃCA
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. The scale of VAT fraud in the European Union is huge, it is not entirely clear what. Cooperation between Member States in the fight against fraud is simply necessary. The ECR Group supports the Commission and the Council in the fight against VAT fraud or avoidance, particularly in the area of e-commerce.  It seems necessary to construct better laws, better tools so that we can create a situation where companies that want to grow do not suffer from this legislation, nor consumers who want to benefit from the market. Clarity in the protection and collection of personal data is also a challenge – this is, of course, where cooperation with the European Data Protection Supervisor is necessary. We should obtain information about an unfair seller established outside the country of consumption, and the money saved can be directed to other important areas of state activity, as in Poland. Poland has been fighting tax fraud very effectively in recent years, and the money from this fight has been spent on social issues.  A determination is therefore needed to effectively fight the VAT gap, which will bring glory to all the countries of the European Union and will clean up the law.

name: Emmanuel MAUREL
text: Madam President, it is true that globalisation and the dematerialisation of purchases have seen the emergence of all kinds of scammers who massively cheat on VAT, to the point that the gap between what should be collected and what really is, for Europe, is EUR 137 billion. For my own country, France, it is almost 12 billion euros, that is three times the deficit of our pension system. It's colossal. The text, of course, refers to the Member States, whose coordination is ineffective and whose tax administration is not sufficiently vigilant. But we also need to talk about the real culprits, i.e., in particular, of all e-commerce operators. We are talking about online payment services, but I want us to focus on all the sales platforms like Amazon, Alibaba, Cdiscount, which are a real blind spot in our common thinking and are absolutely not bothered to market products that are not subject to VAT. For example, in France, 98% of those who go through Amazon and others are not even registered for VAT. So we need a response to the level of the issue because, here we have real tax evaders, and Europe cannot just let these multinationals not pay taxes as they should.

name: Ivan Vilibor SINČIĆ
text: – Dear Chairman, today we are talking about tax fraud. When it comes to tax fraud in Croatia, we cannot help but touch Agrokor, one major group that fell into insolvency proceedings two years ago, which is the largest such in Southeast Europe.  It is a group of about seventy companies with about 60,000 employees, and in this example it turned out to be true everything I have said since my entry into politics, which is that there are double standards in Croatia, that there is no rule of law and that there is no social justice in Croatia. It turns out that if you know the right people, you can do whatever you want without anyone being able to do anything to you.  Let's start with the order. There are about 600 large taxpayers in Croatia. In the 20-odd years in 146 firms, of those 600, no tax surveillance has ever been carried out. There's never been a tax inspector. Many of these companies are from the Agrokor Group. In 252 companies there has never been corporate tax surveillance, in 378 companies there has never been income and contribution control, and finally, which is today's topic, in 170 of these 600 companies there has never been VAT control, although under tax laws the priority of the Croatian state is tax surveillance in large companies. That didn't happen in practice.  Mr. Todorić, who owned Agrokor, benefited him in every way for years, so reports were falsified, all of which were tolerated for decades. He was issuing vouchers, exchanges without cover, and that's where the double standard proved. On the other hand, to small taxpayers, especially those ineparable, the inspection came regularly, carried out terror against them. All this clearly shows that these measures are not enough and that Croatia will remain the Wild West and Eldorado for tax non-payment.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: – Madam President, I believe that the fight against tax fraud should be one of the main tasks of the competent authorities and institutions of the European Union. In addition to comfort and savings, a globalised market, new financial instruments and digitalisation bring new opportunities for various criminals. Fraud is becoming increasingly sophisticated, and states themselves have fewer and fewer options to detect them. We know that in 2017, total value added tax evasion amounted to a wholly eur 137 billion. This means that every tenth euro that was to be ended, to be chosen by individual states, ended up in the pockets of the mafia. That is the money that all citizens have lost. The seriousness of this issue is also underlined by the fact that it was the tax crimes that led to the deaths of journalists Daphne Caruana Galizia and Ján Kuciak with their partner. We live in an era when information becomes the most valuable commodity. It is therefore essential that national authorities share as much data as possible and are able to evaluate objectively and possibly use it in criminal proceedings. It is necessary to put in place mechanisms to prevent leaks using so-called cryptocurrencies. It is also common practice for fraudsters to start fictitious firms in different Member States of the Union and subsequent complex business transactions between them. In doing so, they take advantage of differences in legislation and poor mutual communication between the authorities. We can eliminate these vulnerabilities. I believe that the new European Commission will identify them and, in cooperation with the European Parliament, we will be able to reduce the amount we lose from tax fraud to a minimum. We need to do everything we can to simplify the tax system and help expose those who abuse it. Our citizens deserve it.

name: Zbigniew KUŹMIUK
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The VAT gap across the Union reaches EUR 140 billion per year, as has already been said several times in this House. This is almost a one-year EU budget, although the distribution of this gap to individual Member States is indeed uneven. My country, Poland, has narrowed this gap over the last three years from 24% in 2015 to 12% in 2018, and this year the gap will fall below 10%. I hope that other countries will follow the example of Polish.  The Commission's and the Council's legislative proposal responds in a balanced manner to the new challenges faced by member states' tax authorities, especially given the growing role of platforms facilitating e-commerce but at the same time hindering the tasks of the tax administration. Harmonising the way in which information on payments by intermediaries is collected and information exchanged between countries proposed in this legislation, including the establishment of institutions for the management and operation of the central payment system, the so-called CESOP, should bring tangible benefits to all Member States.

name: Barbara THALER
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, dear audiences in front of the screens! I speak in this House as an MEP to the European Parliament and today also as an IT entrepreneur. We have heard that in 2017 the EU VAT gap was around EUR 137 billion. That is not quite one-seventh of the entire current multiannual financial framework, or the same amount we have spent on competitiveness, growth, and jobs – in seven years' time, mind you. This makes it abundantly clear how urgently regulations need to be put in place to prevent VAT fraud. One reason for the growing gap is special VAT fraud in e-commerce. But a Member State alone rarely has the means or all the necessary information and therefore has little chance of getting to deal with the problem. With this proposal, we now have a strong instrument in the Member States' hands to ensure and control fair conditions of competition for international trade and e-commerce. In doing so, we will also send a positive signal to all the small and medium-sized enterprises that already bear the bulk of the tax burden.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, I put all my hope in you because this subject we also debated in the last mandate. Obviously, of course, the Commission, we, Parliament, have tried to find tools to counter VAT evasion. Sure, the Commission has identified a few. We also have tools, we have Eurofisc, the instrument by which Member States transmit their information. Unfortunately, there is cross-border VAT evasion, there is also e-commerce, there is also exports, there is also between Member States and third countries. There are also fictitious purchases.  What should we do - identify other tools to put an end to - because it's not micro-enterprises, not small and medium-sized enterprises doing evasion - ? There's a link to economic crime. VAT evasion is placed in this area and I think we need to find other tools that lead to a reduction. I stress, however, that compared to 2016, when we had 150 billion, it has fallen a bit, but Commissioner, I think you have a lot of work to do on this issue.

name: Vlad-Marius BOTOŞ
text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I fully agree that a common approach is needed in quantifying and analysing VAT collection. The creation of a central electronic payment information system is a viable solution only to the extent that Member States will be able to join this system and provide optimal cooperation in terms of the input of the necessary data.  I must, however, draw attention to the fact that there are Member States which do not have the administrative and technical capacity to collect and provide all the necessary data in real time and to adapt rapidly to technical developments. We must not lose sight of the fact that it is necessary to find from the outset the solution to bring and maintain administrative and technical capacities at the same level in all Member States. At the same time, we must ensure that there are mechanisms for rapid adaptation and the evolution and development of the CESOP centralised system that respects the trend of European economic digitisation.

name: Tudor CIUHODARU
text: – Madam President, Mr Gentiloni, I must admit that I am extremely concerned. I am in the European Parliament for the first time, and when you hear that this fraud is equivalent to the European Union budget, you can only ask yourself big questions about whether this money that should be used for health, education or infrastructure goes in other directions.  At first I find that idea of a centralised system at European level absolutely reasonable, but I was of the same opinion: who puts it into practice? On the other hand, perhaps it is time to think about prevention. There would be fair taxation in all European countries at prevention.  Prevention would also mean controlling those multinationals whose problems arose today in the plenary of the European Parliament and, why not, if we are talking about such large sums, you may find that on that common platform you can work with a new institution, with the European Public Prosecutor, so that these things are detected and sanctioned and in such a way that , perhaps, let us no longer witness these hijackings.  Thank you, I wish you success and to be honest, I would not want to be in your shoes because it seems more and more like a battle with windmills.

name: Tudor CIUHODARU
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank you all for the quality of our debate, and also for the very large support to the proposals that we are discussing. I will make only two remarks. One is, as many of you have said, administrative cooperation will be key in this process and Member States’ tax authorities should make full use of the new and existing instruments. Second, we obviously need to take new steps forward – ambitious ones – because of the dimension of the problem that we are facing. We will work hand in hand.  I would like to inform you that the Commission will organise a conference to discuss how tax compliance and the fight against fraud can be improved.  I hope that your input to this conference will be valuable. From this conference, we will bring results to the new Action Plan on fighting fraud and ensuring compliance, as I said before. I strongly welcome and value the contribution of the Parliament in these issues. You can count on my full commitment to work with you in the next five years to ensure a fair tax environment in Europe. This, I think, is a common commitment of the Commission and the Parliament.

name: Lídia PEREIRA
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I thank you for the contributions of all, who value this debate and show how committed we are to combating tax evasion in the Union and, in particular, in the fight against VAT fraud. These reports reflect a thoughtful ambition based on the certainty that digitisation is changing our lives every day. Therefore, legislating today means more than finding general and abstract solutions: it also means finding concrete solutions to problems which, in detail, can become significant harm, damage to the public office of the Member States, to the general budget of the Union and, indeed, to the family budget of Europeans. VAT fraud in e-commerce in the European Union is growing because e-commerce in the Union is increasing. Often, protecting the internal market requires us to know how to wait and let the market work. That's not the case. We are legislating in this way because we believe in a fair market in which taxation and tax obligations can be an instrument of justice and protection of businesses and citizens. It is true that these reports are about VAT in e-commerce, but they can be a signal from this sector to the major VAT reform that we aim for Europe. A reform for taxation better adapted to the challenges of the digital economy, more ambitious in building a European budget focused on cohesion, convergence and competitiveness. Taxes are inevitable, as we know. Our challenge is to make them an instrument at the service of our economies, growth and jobs.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: The joint debate is closed. The vote will take place on Tuesday, 17 December 2019.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: The next item is the joint debate on – the report by Irene Tinagli, on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, on the Council recommendation on the appointment of a Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank (12451/2019 – C9-0149/2019 – 2019/0817(NLE)) (A9—0049/2019), and – the report by Irene Tinagli, on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, on the Council recommendation on the appointment of a Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank (13651/2019 – C9-0173/2019 – 2019/0818(NLE)) (A9-0046/2019). I remind you that it is possible to request catch-the-eye and blue cards, using the standard registration and the electronic system. Instructions are available at the entrance of the Hemicycle.

name: Irene TINAGLI
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, with these two reports that will be voted tomorrow, the European Parliament expresses its non-binding opinion on the appointment of two new members of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank. Over the last month, the Council has recommended the names of Fabio Panetta and Isabel Schnabel and on both candidates the European Central Bank has expressed its positive opinion. The curricula vitae sent to us by the President of the European Council clearly show how both candidates are persons of recognised standing and professional experience in monetary or banking matters, as required by Article 238 of the Treaty. Fabio Panetta has spent his professional career of over 30 years as a central banker. He has served in important positions at national, European and international level, and he is currently the senior Deputy Governor of the Bank of Italy. Isabel Schnabel is a distinguished scholar of one of the most prestigious European universities and for five years she has been a member of the Council of Economic Advisers of Germany.  The ECON Committee submitted to the two candidates a written questionnaire of over 50 questions and subsequently organised a public hearing. The vast support received by Fabio Panetta and Isabel Schnabel, 90% and 70% respectively, demonstrates the very wide appreciation of the ECON Committee for these two excellent candidates.  However, the two reports do not simply express our support for Fabio Panetta and Isabel Schnabel; they recall and renew battles that the European Parliament has been fighting for some time.  First and foremost, the battle for a selection and appointing procedure that involved the Parliament more. Of course, we appreciated that after our requests the President of the Eurogroup, Mário Centeno, by publicly announcing which nominations had been received for each position, has made the selection process more transparent than in the past. However, we reiterate our request that the Council, before each of its recommendations, submits to the Parliament a list of at least two names where at least one man and one woman are present.  Only in this way will it be possible to guarantee equal opportunities for men and women in the selection procedures for top positions in our institutions, and therefore to favour gender balance in management bodies. We already have achieved some important results in this regard. In the last six months, half of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank was renewed, and two out of the three new members are women. One third of the Executive Board will be composed by women, and let us not forget that one of them has been appointed as the President of the ECB.  However, this is not enough. A few months ago, European newspapers published a photo of the ECB Governing Council, that is the other management body of the ECB, and there was only one woman in that picture – Madame Lagarde herself.  Of course this is not due to the nomination process we are discussing; this is due to the fact that the non-executive part of the ECB Governing Council is composed by all the governors of the national central banks of the euro area, and all of them happen to be men.  This makes it clear that our aim for a gender-balanced representation in European bodies can be reached only if this process takes place everywhere in national institutions first. For this reason, we call on the Council to forward our message to all Member States.  To conclude, I just want to say that our support for these two excellent candidates, and our responsibility in guaranteeing the correct and regular functioning of the ECB, while safeguarding interinstitutional cooperation, shall not diminish our battles which we will continue fighting with determination in the future.

name: Irene TINAGLI
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members of the Parliament, honourable Irene Tinagli, we all know how relevant the role of the European Central Bank is to our economy. The Bank has played a crucial role in managing the recent crisis. Monetary policy has successfully used the instruments at its disposal to stimulate the economy, and as a result, it has averted a serious threat of deflation. I’m glad to see a discussion on your agenda on these two appointments, specifically for two reasons. Firstly, for reasons of democratic accountability. The Treaties enshrine the independence of the European Central Bank, and this is a principle that the Commission defends wholeheartedly, but independence and accountability are two sides of the same coin. Secondly, as you can see from the composition of the College and the cabinets of Commissioners, this Commission is committed to the promotion of gender equality. It is my conviction that public institutions, such as the Commission and the ECB, have a particular responsibility in this respect. I therefore support the Parliament’s endeavour for gender balance in all European bodies, which was underlined by the honourable Ms Tinagli right now. As you were very right to point out in your resolution earlier this year, all of us working in the economic field need to move to do more on this front. However, we need to be careful to facilitate the functioning of the ECB in these important times, not least when the institution is not to blame for faults in the nomination process. It should also be highlighted that the ECB itself has stepped up its efforts on that front in recent years. I know you will make sure that it continues to strive for gender equality under the leadership of President Lagarde. After all, the positions expressed by this Parliament have already yielded results, following the appointment of Madame Lagarde and the election of Ursula von der Leyen as President of the Commission, women finally fill two of the most crucial positions in the EU. I look forward to hearing your views and to continuing our good cooperation with the European Central Bank.

name: Markus FERBER
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. The Executive Board of the European Central Bank is undergoing a personnel shake-up this year. With Christine Lagarde, Isabelle Schnabel and Fabio Panetta, there are new faces on the Governing Council, and if I add mr Lane to this list, there are four new members of the Executive Board within a very short space of time. This is certainly also a good reason to question some of the old methods and priorities of the European Central Bank.  In this respect, the review of the Central Bank's monetary policy strategy, which was last carried out in 2003, is the right step. However, I believe that in these reviews we should also reduce the desires somewhat, because the mandate of the European Central Bank is not being reviewed, the mandate is derived from the Treaties. And if you want to change the mandate, you have to get involved in the Treaties. It is not the ECB's job to give itself a new mandate. What is possible, however, is to reconsider what price stability means in the 21st century. The Chief Economist of the European Central Bank recently described the structural factors affecting our economy: demographic change, the shift to a service society, and increased demand for safe investment products. All these factors are pushing down interest rates. However, if this analysis is correct, then the ECB must also take the next step. In other words, if the equilibrium interest rate falls in the long term, the monetary policy of the European Central Bank should also adjust. There is no point in dogmatically sticking to the 2% inflation target if we themselves forecast lower growth rates in the medium and long term. In this respect, the ECB should urgently review this part of its policy so that savings also generate a lasting profit.
