As the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, we will support both nominations and we expect to work closely with the European Parliament.

name: Jonás FERNÁNDEZ
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Madam President, welcome, Commissioner, tomorrow we will vote on these nominations to complete the ECB's governing body, and I believe that the two candidates who have passed the review process by the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, a few weeks ago, are perfectly eligible to assist in the ECB's monetary policy direction. And it is a change that also coincides with the election of the new president of the institution and therefore opens a new period; a new period in which I believe that the activity of the European Central Bank needs to be reviewed. I agree that the Bank's mandate is clearly in the Treaties, but the way in which that mandate translates into the specific objectives and the instruments for implementing that monetary policy is obviously part of the debate. The ECB's current monetary policy strategy was agreed as early as 2003, more than fifteen years ago, and many things have happened since then: the natural interest rate on money has fallen in response to demographic changes and the challenges of digitization, and therefore the ability to implement monetary policies is greatly constrained by this permanent fall in the natural interest rate. That is why we need to seek other objectives, within the mandate, but other objectives. We need to look at whether we can incorporate asset prices, or whether we need to set that inflation target not so much in price growth, but at the price level itself. And we also need to review the instruments in a digital world that opens up a new ground for monetary policy. And for all this, I believe that we have an ECB prepared and the two people we will vote on tomorrow bring clarity and principles to that debate.

name: Luis GARICANO
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Madam President. The European Central Bank has been the only institution that has acted with the interest of resolving the crisis — the latest crisis — on behalf of all Europeans. Unfortunately, judging by the news coming to us from certain States, this fact does not seem to be so clear in public opinion. Some complain that the ECB does too much, and they may be right, but what they don't say is that if the European Central Bank is doing a lot, it is because monetary policy is being the only tool being used against the crisis and states are not doing their part. Monetary policy cannot be the only instrument for combating a recession. The European Union needs effective countercyclical mechanisms to complement its action, such as common European unemployment insurance or a budget for the euro area — and the budget has to be the right size, not what the Eurogroup seems to be agreeing on.  We want and believe in an independent European Central Bank, an institution that tells the truth, however uncomfortable, and the truth is that Member States must do more. We are therefore pleased that the two candidates on which we are speaking today have accepted, before the Committee on Economic Affairs of this Parliament, to make the European Central Bank an institution committed to the reforms necessary to strengthen the euro area.  On the other hand, complaints about the ECB are not only because it has already been forced to use both its monetary policy, but are also explained by mis-communication. We have to combat misinformation and monetary populism. We cannot allow sensational media from some countries to say that the ECB steals money from savers and pensioners. We need the European Union to have a clear account of this. We must be able to defend our institutions and explain to our citizens why the decisions of the European Central Bank were and are right. This is not an exclusive task of the European Central Bank. We too, from the European Parliament, need to be more active in condemning the lies of populists and explaining our decisions. But not only do we have to explain the political decisions: also the techniques. We need to explain to citizens the ideas that motivate us to make the decisions we make. The European Central Bank's action must be credible, and it depends on everyone's effort that our single currency, one of our greatest successes, has a prosperous future.  This communication challenge is the challenge that future members of the Executive Committee of the European Central Bank, Isabel Schnabel and Fabio Panetta will also have ahead of them. From Renew Europe we know that they understand the situation and we believe they are trained to help solve it. That's why we're voting for your appointments. We believe they are trained to make the right decisions and that they are both trained to help explain these decisions.  As the chairwoman of our committee has said, we would also like to highlight a problem in these appointments and in this procedure, which has to do with the problem of gender parity. Citizens cannot feel represented by a Governing Council in which half of citizenship is not represented, as only twenty-four members are women. Faced with this situation, the European Parliament, through a resolution adopted in March this year, demanded that States submit two names to fill each vacancy: a man and a woman. Among them, Parliament would choose the most qualified. If you don't put women's names on the table, it's impossible for us to achieve gender equality. States must do more in their competitive field. All governors of national central banks are men. I'm a professor of economics. I have dedicated myself to this twenty-five years and I can assure you that there are many highly trained women in my profession, and I find it very difficult to understand why it is so difficult to find them. That must change. I honestly think it is a disgrace that the picture that President Tinagli was talking about and should not be repeated, and in that regard we ask the Member States to do their part.

name: Sven GIEGOLD
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her We Greens support Isabel Schnabel and Fabio Panetta for this task. However, we must take this opportunity to point out how this happened. For many years, this Parliament has been arguing for us to have more gender balance in the EU's central financial positions, and to this day we have not succeeded. One has to add for the sake of honesty: not even with ourselves. What has happened here, however, is that Parliament has said very clearly that we always want balanced lists in the future, so that we can then decide on the basis of qualifications and the inclusion of the two sexes here. And the Council has again not accepted this, it has not been able to do so, because top positions are still being made the subject of national estates, where it is said that it is now a matter of an Italian, then a German, then a Frenchman, then someone from a small country. But you don't get the most qualified candidates, nor do you get a reasonable gender balance. That is why we need an interinstitutional agreement from the Council of the Member States on how we can strike a reasonable balance here in the future, without damaging the individual candidates. And the Commission is called upon to help here to obtain such an interinstitutional agreement on the filling of top positions in the European institutions in the financial field. However, one must also ask ourselves whether this is only about personnel and individual positions. Would it really have been the case if a woman had sat before the ECB that she had already set the monetary policy strategy for years when a man comes? Mario Draghi has done nothing else by, in fact, ensnating the low interest rate policy for the future. That is why I think it is right that the new leader has said that we are revising the monetary policy strategy. And this is the right opportunity, within the framework of the contractual tasks, both to promote the greening of the ECB's monetary policy and supervisory policy and to take more attention to the side effects of low interest rates policy. After all, the risk of corresponding asset price bubbles is real, and it is also true that both the candidates we are now appointing and Christine Lagarde have made it clear that only with a common fiscal policy, with the completion of economic and monetary union and the banking union can interest rate policy change. And this house should be working on this.

name: Antonio Maria RINALDI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, our delegation has expressed its support for the appointment of Dr Fabio Panetta to the Board of the European Central Bank, welcoming the Italian member-designate, as he has continuously demonstrated over time a high profile of competence, professionalism and independence, reaching the top management from the Bank of Italy with exclusive criteria of merit. , one of the most prestigious Italian institutions.  We would, however, like to draw the attention of the House on this occasion in the hope that the new Board of the European Central Bank, in its total statutory independence, will reconsider the policy of negative interest rates, because their permanence over time is creating a paradoxical situation, for which, on the one hand, the enormous liquidity provided in the face of the extraordinary monetary stimulus undertaken in recent years has not been able to reach , if not marginally, the real economy, i.e. households and businesses in the eurozone, and, on the other hand, has also created huge sustainability problems in individual and collective investment assets, such as pension funds.  In addition, we very much hope that a calendar provisioning will finally be prepared without delay to establish the criteria for monitoring OTC instruments, i.e. those classified as level 2 and level 3 in order to protect savers, as well as the financial stability of the entire eurozone from its major and effective sources of risk. Finally, we trust that the Board of the European Central Bank itself will carefully assess whether the current forecast of ESMA's preparatory evaluation powers, extended to the sustainability of a Member State's debt, according to the unambiguous criterion set out in Annex 3 does not automatically lead to negative market expectations on the placement of public securities, since the effects would be unpredictable and therefore very risky due to the total , opaque and arbitrary chosen in the application of the quantitative method.

name: Johan VAN OVERTVELDT
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Mr President, Commissioner Gentiloni, the European Central Bank has been pursuing a very expansionary policy for over ten years, for which there were of course very good reasons during the financial crisis and the acute phase of the euro crisis. However, we are currently seeing an increasing unintended impact on the continued use of this policy. This results in, among other things, an attack on savings, pressure on productivity, because more and more so-called 'zombie companies' are being kept alive, and a constant pressure on financial stability. So there is a lot of work to be done for the new President and the two directors or directors-elect we are talking about today, Mrs Schnabel and Mr Panetta. Both have made a very good impression as far as I am concerned during the hearings and will therefore receive our support. Finally, I would like to return to the following, particularly curious expression by Mrs Schnabel during her hearing: 'There are very few people who understand what is really going on'. I immediately protested against this and Mrs Schnabel responded positively to it. In fact, she has pledged to do her best to make the communication of central bankers clearer and more understandable to the average citizen.

name: José GUSMÃO
text: gue/NGL Group. – Madam President, during the years of Mario Draghi extraordinary monetary policy instruments have been mobilised. However, the growth of these years has been mediocre and these instruments have risks and consequences that should not be ignored. In hearings with members who will now be appointed, we wanted to know if we agree on the importance of having a combination of policies in the European Union, particularly with much more significant budgetary instruments than those that currently exist, we wanted to know what they think about the ECB looking more at the issue of employment and inequalities, even if it means greater latitude in the inflation targets, and we wanted to know what ideas they have so that the ECB can play a role in responding to climate change or that at least does not spoil. The answers we had from Fabio Panetta were, from our point of view, satisfactory, which is why we will support his candidacy. Mrs Schnabel's answers were not so satisfactory, but we also do not want to make it impossible precisely because of concern about gender balance. We join all the groups that have talked about the importance of Member States taking responsibility for this goal which is an objective that should unite us all to have gender balance in future appointments.

name: Stefan BERGER
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has I too would like to be the first to wish Mrs Schnabel and Mr Panetta a happy hand for their future task. The whole of Europe is looking at the reorientation of the European Central Bank's personnel. We should use this moment of pause in substance to make a few comments. We have been living for years in a period of ultra-loose monetary policy and the expansion of the money supply. If you look at the results of this policy, you can see that the Monetary Policy of the European Central Bank is hitting a path of inequality through Europe. Not all companies are shareholders' companies. Many companies in Europe are also companies of savers, and these savings are melting away, and in addition, the banks whose business model is being threatened by this policy are trying to solve their difficulties by turning the screw on savers' fees. The fact is that the independence of the European Central Bank is a great asset. That is why I am also appealing to the newly elected personalities, whom we also support in the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, to be a voice in favour of these arguments on the Executive Board of the European Central Bank. It would perhaps still make sense to start a debate on whether the 2% inflation target is actually still up-to-date and whether it really needs to be achieved at all costs. I therefore hope that the current personnel changes can be combined with a substantive debate on a change of course by the European Central Bank. I wish all those involved every success in this.

name: Pedro MARQUES
text: – Madam President, a new political cycle is now well under way. A bold agenda for the future of Europe was set and it is now time to deliver. We expect the European Central Bank – its Executive Board, from its President to those who are now appointed – to play their role in the European priorities. We have to move forward, being able to agree on smaller things, but also on the hard reforms. We cannot keep betting on the prolongation of this economic cycle without doing anything else. We cannot rely solely on monetary policy, which is of the utmost importance but is not sufficient. We need a strong investment plan and we have to build a budget for the stabilisation that we know we’ll need in the difficult moments that eventually will come sometime. We need to act on the climate and on the economy, but also on social cohesion. The ECB has an important role and we have to analyse its mandate, taking into account modern European priorities. But we will also hold these Executive Board members accountable for its President’s pledge to keep the previous stance of monetary policy throughout this next term because this is where it will make a difference: if we have from the European Central Bank and from its Executive Board the trust that monetary policy will keep its adaptive stance. And then we have to do the rest on the rest of the economic policy.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: – Madam President, the European Central Bank's unconventional measures have kept the euro afloat. Because of the lack of action by the Member States, it had to be the ECB, with these measures, that kept the single currency safe. It cannot be hinted that these measures have been outside the law— as some do — not least because those who have wanted to pleite and bring to the Luxembourg Court some of these measures have done so and the Court has validated each and every one of the measures taken by the ECB so far. But it is clear that we need to look at the risks that some of these measures have had in terms of the bubble, for example, produced in the housing market or also other effects that have destabilized the financial market. And it is also necessary to review, as the European Central Bank will do in the coming months, the whole monetary policy to adapt it to new phenomena such as – and that is very important for this group as well – its effects on climate change, knowing that the Bank's asset purchase programmes have been buying coal-linked assets for many and many months and that must end , among many other things. As regards the candidacies of Mr Panetta and Mrs Schnabel, it seems to us that in their appearances they responded positively to many of these challenges, so this group will support them, but I would also like to join my voice and point out that we cannot continue to allow the Council to continue without presenting us with parity lists of candidates. I believe that Mrs Lagarde's photo of more than twenty men around her and her as the only woman on the Governing Council of the European Central Bank is totally insulting. I believe that, as has been said in this House, there are excellent women prepared, good professionals to hold the top positions in the European financial institutions and, therefore, it is the responsibility of this House, but also of all the institutions, to guarantee it. Therefore, from now on, as we have already asked in this Parliament, we want paritarian lists — paritarian shortlists - in order to ensure this gender equality. If not, and if the Council continues to speak deafly to this House request, what I augur are more problems in the ratification of future members. So, for the sake of the institutional functioning of all these institutions, I hope that these parity lists will already be a reality.

name: Herve JUVIN
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I have examined the career paths and the extensive competences of the two candidates proposed to us, and I, for one, see no reason to oppose them which is not equally enforceable against many members of this honourable Council of the ECB. I would like to ask the question of the diversity of this Council. Secular stagnation, unrealistic - or not - of a target of 2% annual inflation, the proliferation of electronic currencies or virtual currencies, the subject of the 'helicopter currency' which could lead central banks to encroach not only on fiscal policies, but also on the social policies of the Member States: all these issues are totally new because we are in a new monetary and economic world. All over the world, neoclassical theories have failed. Global theories and free trade have failed around the world. And all over the world, what made the election of Donald Trump, what just elected Boris Johnson, is at work and will be at work in the European Union. I believe that issues of sovereignty and economic nationalism are on the agenda. I believe we are entering a new world of monetary and economic policies. That is why, when I talk about diversity, I would like to question this House. Would it not be necessary for professionals and experts from the digital economy to be included in the ECB Council? Experts in political science, who would remind us that the currency - a fundamental instrument of sovereignty - is still a political instrument - an instrument of trust and stability of societies? Finally, I will mention the subject of ecology: a currency will not be sustainable if it is imposed in a world that is not itself sustainable. For my part, I would like to see specialists in ecological science also find their place in this Council, which would thus gain in diversity.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: – Madam President, we know that the ECB going into next year’s financial or strategic review is a house divided. I welcome the new President’s call for fiscal stimulus to be used to complement monetary policy. But the irony isn’t lost on any of us who have been at the receiving end of its threats and blackmail that the ECB has been the chief enforcer of austerity over the past decade. Now that the manufacturing base in the northern states is threatened, it seems that the tune is changing. The ECB review needs to be more than just a bun fight between the so-called hawks and doves. We need a serious analysis of the consequences of ECB policy and its impact on people right across the eurozone, including the dangerous housing bubbles pricing a generation out of the market. Above all, the ECB needs to face the fact that its policies have helped massively inflate the wealth of a very tiny minority while doing almost nothing for the ordinary families and workers of the EU. So all options must now be on the table going forward, including direct payments to households and a direct Green Investment Scheme.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, allow me to add a few words about the appointment of Fabio Panetta as a member of the Executive Board of the ECB. Italy will be present on the board with a high-level professional, a figure of recognized competence in the banking sector and monetary policy. Fabio Panetta also has a leading career within the ECB itself, having regularly participated in the meetings of the Governing Council together with the Governor of the Bank of Italy and, on some occasions, even in his place. More recently, he was also a member of the Supervisory Board of the European Banking Supervision System. In recent years he has been a deep observer of the most difficult moments of the economic and financial crisis, analyzing its causes and scenarios, a recognized profile of competence and correctness that has tenaciously supported European interests. He arrives in Frankfurt at a sensitive time, marked by serious tensions in the Governing Council and several challenges open to the table of the bank's new leadership: from climate change to cryptocurrencies, from the issues of money laundering supervision to the stalemate of the Banking Union, but I am and we are sure that this is a choice of merit and that it will certainly live up to the principles in which he has always shown that he believes during his excellent career.

name: Paul TANG
text: – Madam President, welcome, Commissioner Gentiloni. Sometimes a picture says more than a thousand words. When Lagarde tweeted a photo of her first ECB governing council, it said more than any of us could ever say. Flanked by baroque paintings and underneath a classic chandelier, smiling at the camera were the faces of Ms Lagarde and 24 men. I had to look again. Is this really 2019? Were it not for the iPads on the conference tables, I would have thought it was from the days of De Gaulle or from Jean Monnet instead of Sanna Marin. As an economist by training, I know that many of us are used to male-dominated settings and have become desensitised. But this photo should awaken us. It shows that the battle for gender-equality remains urgent and one that concerns us all. This is why, not only I personally, but also the Social Democrats and the European Parliament call on the Council to put forward two candidates for ECB positions: a man and a woman. I know this might be a long shot. Nominations are proposed by the Eurogroup, which holds among its 19 members just one woman. But – and I’m firm on this – if the Council doesn’t update its appointment procedure to the 21st century, we should vote against it. How can we get fair decisions when half of our population is all but excluded from decision-making? How can our policies create a modern economy when they are made in a setting of an age long gone? Schnabel and Panetta have both committed to promoting gender-equality upon their appointment. They have a hell of a job to do. I hope they will put their words into action.

name: Roman HAIDER
text: Madam President, Commissioner, this House, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his work and for the work she has The European Central Bank is therefore closing its ranks. From President Lagarde's point of view, this is also understandable, because it is now becoming increasingly clear how devastating this fatal low interest rate policy by the ECB is across the euro area. Savers are being expropriated in the benefit of bankrupt governments and junk companies, the housing market is increasingly overheating, rents and land prices are rising into unaffordable prices, bubbles are emerging, and the wealth gap – driven by this policy – is widening. Social tensions are the result. The retirement provision of millions of EU citizens is at risk. This has long since ceased to have nothing to do with price stability, the real task of the European Central Bank. The only beneficiaries are speculators and bankrupt governments. In view of this truly devastating record, it is not critical spirit that is needed, but squad obedience. And that is probably the most important point that speaks for Mrs Schnabel, especially when we know that her three German predecessors on the ECB Executive Board have all resigned prematurely in protest at this very disastrous low interest rate policy. Obedience to the cadre without a spirit of contradiction – but this will continue to be very, very important in the Future in the European Central Bank. For ms. Lagarde is going far beyond her legal mandate by announcing that she will abuse the ECB for a completely misguided climate policy in the future. Breaking the law thus becomes a sad tradition in the ECB. The interests of the citizens no longer count at all, and the ECB will finally become a lobbying organisation for speculators and pleitiers. Unfortunately, it can only be insinuated from what she has said so far that Mrs Schnabel will also support this policy against the citizen. Too bad about it.

name: Evelyn REGNER
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. We women make up half of the population and therefore earn half the world. We earn half the bakery and not just a piece of the cake. We women deserve to be adequately represented in decision-making functions, whether that is now in the European Central Bank, eBA, ESMA, EIOPA, wherever it is, ESRB, and not just in individual – very hard-won – positions!  Everyone, and we have mentioned it many times now, knows this image of ECB chief Lagarde, lonely in the men's round. This is embarrassing and does not correspond to the Europe of the 21st century. We women– smart women, like smart men, need us at all levels of decision-making. We want and we have to help shape it. Instead of the exception, mixed teams should become the rule. We have a lot to say when it comes to a sustainable investment offensive for Europe. When it comes to using proper monetary policy to boost our economy, fight together against rigid fiscal rules, and push the transition to a fair and green economy. So, representatives of the Council, ministers, governments: slide over and let women finally play a part. Commissioner, you can see that the existing nomination process, as it is, is ready for scrapping. Give us ME Members of the European Parliament strong support for revising and redesigning this procedure.

name: Gunnar BECK
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for his work and for the work she has In mid-November, Ms Schnabel urged German economists via Twitter to refrain from making damaging and false statements about the ECB. Such criticism, mrs Schnabel says, threatens the euro. Just like the displeasure with negative interest rates on the part of German savers, which Mrs Schnabel simply dismissed as financial illiterate. According to the OECD and prominent economists, the ECB has failed. With its monetary policy, it created the lowest growth, the highest taxes, and the most unemployed in the developed world. The ECB itself has admitted in its Financial Stability Review that its money glut has led to overvalued stock prices and higher government and corporate debt in crisis countries. According to the DZ-Bank, ECB policy alone has cost German savers almost €650 billion in lost interest income since 2010, while the Bundesbank has pulverized nearly one trillion euros of target loans to bail out the euro.  Are these the truths that Mrs Schnabel wants to suppress? We, on the other hand, want the competition of ideas as the best guide to the truth.

name: Maximilian KRAH
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for her excellent report I have listened with interest to the speeches, particularly those of Mr Berger, a member of the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, who has told us that there are two types of companies, those of shareholders and those of savers. The candidate, Fabio Panetta, made it clear when he stated that the ECB's rules do not fit the bank bailout for Italy. He is right, but that shows that a single currency does not work when completely different economic schools of thought meet. How one can cheer these nominations at the same time, given this realization that there are different basic economic structures, remains, of course, the secret of the EPP and the German CDU. It goes without saying that Fabio Panetta represents the interests of Italy and the shareholder and owner company. He is fantastically trained for this and has the necessary academic prerequisites. But why Then Germany proposes Mrs Schnabel, who also represents the interests of the owner economies and works against the German savers, even criticizes the criticism of the wrong policy, that remains the secret of the German Federal Government. Of course, the Socialists always shoot the bird, Mrs Regner. This is about money, not half the bakery. And it is therefore a question of quality and qualifications, and it is not gender-dependent. But perhaps, as a socialist, you would rather eat cake than think about economics.

name: Ewa KOPACZ
text: Thank you very much, Mr President. Since we do not have any reports from the Chamber, Commissioner Gentiloni will speak on behalf of the Commission. Please, Commissioner.

name: Ewa KOPACZ
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, before concluding, I think it is appropriate to thank Benoît Cœuré for the outstanding work he has done as a member of the ECB Executive Board over the past eight years. We are also grateful to Sabine Lautenschläger for her contribution as a member of the ECB Executive Board, as well as for her role in helping set up and steer Europe’s banking supervision. As you know, the Commission is not involved in the appointment process, but for sure, we appreciate the two new members of the Executive Board and their qualifications and we share the European Parliament’s commitment, that was repeated here by several honourable Members, to a more adequate gender balance in the Bank and in all our economic bodies. We have a great interest in listening to your views, also on macroeconomic policy-making in the euro area. It was an opportunity today. On this, let me add just one remark. I think that, in recent years, the burden to stimulate the European economy has fallen excessively on monetary policy in the euro area. For a more balanced and more effective policy mix, it should be supported by structural reforms and fiscal policy. Fiscal policy, whilst bearing in mind debt sustainability, especially in highly-indebted Member States, can provide a boost to domestic demand and raise inflation expectations. ECB President Lagarde also stressed this in front of the Parliament recently, and I couldn’t agree more.

name: Ewa KOPACZ
text: I close the debate. The vote will take place on Tuesday 17 December 2019.

name: Ewa KOPACZ
text: The next item is the debate on the oral question to the Commission by Irene Tinagli, on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, on fair taxation in the globalised digital economy – BEPS 2.0 (O-000040/2019 - B9-0060/2019) (2019/2901(RSP)). I would like to remind you that you can apply to speak from the room and to the blue card procedure both traditionally and in the electronic system.  Instructions are available at the entrance to the plenary chamber.

name: Irene TINAGLI
text: author. – Madam President, USD 240 billion dollars: according to OECD estimates this is the amount of missing tax revenues due to multinationals’ tax elusion. Researchers from Berkeley and the University of Copenhagen estimated that in 2016, 40% of big companies’ profits were shifted to tax havens every year. For many countries, this means losing huge portions of tax revenues that could be used to address increasing needs in education, health care, public services and pensions, not to mention investments in physical and digital infrastructures, in research and development: all things that benefit people and firms of all sizes, small and large ones alike. Everybody should contribute to this. But while citizens, consumers and small and medium businesses do pay their share, with effective tax rates that may go up to 40% or even more sometimes, many large multinationals do not, and this is not acceptable anymore. These situations not only create problems of social justice, but also relevant market distortions and unfair competition. We talk a lot about building a level playing field, but what we have today on tax matters is not level at all. Yes, we want to reward efficiency, we want to reward innovation, but that should take place within a fiscal framework that applies the same tax rules to everyone. That is why we welcome the commitment of 135 countries that are negotiating, at the OECD level, a reform to address these challenges. On behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs (ECON), today I present a resolution and oral questions on these reforms, and we urge the Commission and Member States to act and agree on a joint and ambitious EU position in these negotiations. I thank the Commissioner for being here today to answer our questions. The first one: how does the Commission intend to ensure a common EU position in the current international discussions on tax challenges posed by the digitalisation of the economy? And the second: how does the Commission intend to ensure that the ongoing international discussions around Pillar One are coherent and consistent with EU proposals in this field? And third: how is the Commission preparing the implementation of the outcome of such international deals? And, in the event of a regrettable absence of an international solution, when, and in what form, will the Commission act to ensure a coordinated EU reply? Parliament expects an active role of the Commission. Europe can play a fundamental role in shaping this debate only if we are united, only if we speak with one voice. With this initiative, Parliament intends to express its position on two main points. The first one: we should reform the allocation of taxing rights, going beyond the concept of physical presence in order to include all large firms with an active engagement and interaction with customers and users – also by digital means. The second: we encourage a minimum rate to be set at a fair and sufficient level to discourage profit-shifting and prevent damaging tax competition. Indeed, according to the corporate tax statistics by OECD, there are countries where the corporate tax rate is basically zero, and we can’t accept that anymore. So let me conclude, dear Commissioner and dear colleagues, by saying that it’s time to modernise our tax rules to ensure that big companies pay their fair share of taxes where the value is created and where the economic activity is taking place. We should not ring-fence the digital economy, but we should look at all multinationals that are increasingly finding ways to elude taxes. The current international fiscal regime creates competitive distortions among players; it deprives countries from their sovereign decision to tax corporate profits to finance public services; and most importantly, it increases inequalities and puts most of this fiscal burden on less mobile taxpayers, workers and consumers. This is simply not fair. Our citizens demand tax justice, and it is time to give them an answer.

name: Irene TINAGLI
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members of the Parliament, thank you, honourable Tinagli, for putting the reform of the international corporate taxation framework on the agenda of this session. The questions you raised also show how important this issue is for the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs (ECON) and the Special Committee on Financial Crimes, Tax Evasion and Tax Avoidance (TAX3), and for your honourable person. I am also grateful for all the work you have done so far. Whatever the shape of the solutions, the Commission is defending an EU perspective I would like to detail. It is important to continue working in parallel on the twin challenges of modernising international corporate tax rules. One: to tax digital activities, carried out without a physical presence. This concerns the reallocation of taxing rights, the so-called Pillar 1. Two: to address new forms of excessive tax competition under what is called Pillar 2. To address those challenges and reach an ambitious global agreement, we then need to find a global solution that effectively captures digital business models, notably those operating in jurisdictions without a physical presence, and to put a floor on excessive international tax competition and close remaining BEPS loopholes. In addition, while working on a global solution at international level, our aim is to negotiate the best possible outcome for Member States and for the EU. I also want to ensure that the specificities of the Single Market are respected in any solution that arises from the international discussions. We always work for Europeans, in the interest of European businesses and for the sake of European citizens. That is why we aim at achieving these objectives without additional complexities for businesses. It is essential that any new rules be simple and easy to administer and provide additional resources to be redistributed to the benefit of our citizens. Indeed, it is important to understand the economic impact of the options proposed under both pillars, so that Member States can take an informed decision. The preliminary results of our economic analysis on revenues are, until now, encouraging. They suggest that the EU as a whole could benefit under Pillar 1 and that all Member States would benefit from Pillar 2. The Commission has now asked Member States to provide their country-by-country reporting data to be able to further refine the economic analysis. To conclude, if a global agreement is reached on both pillars, the EU will need to decide how it should be implemented at EU level. If no or limited agreement is reached internationally by 2020, it is crystal clear that the strong rationale for EU action at EU level will remain and that the Commission will act on this basis.

name: Markus FERBER
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. First of all, thank you very much, Commissioner, for this clear commitment, for the clear commitment you have just made. I think it is very important that we find a solution, a clarification, for many of the things that we had to find out together in three special committees and in a committee of inquiry during the last parliamentary term. The best solution, of course, is the international one, because tax problems do not stop at the borders of the European Union, but – especially when we are talking about the digital economy – we are dealing with international challenges, and we must also address them together internationally.  That is why I very much welcome the fact that the Member States are taking action here, but also other jurisdictions. I would refer in particular to the United States of America, which has an important role to play here, particularly in the field of the digital economy. We need to get away from the idea of a physical plant, with machines, factories, employees, physical inputs, and physically tangible outputs in the digital economy. It is almost a matter of where you settle, there are other criteria. Unfortunately, it is far too often tax law that ultimately is crucial to where a company is set up. That is precisely why these things need to be addressed. But I also say quite clearly: those who leave must keep their own stable clean. I would like to point out that we also have competition in the European Union at the expense of the partners – dubious competition to the detriment of the partners in the European Union. We must also address our problems clearly and clearly in the European Union. I really call on the Commission to move forward with courage. Not only the Competition Commissioner, by addressing the whole thing as aid issues, but also you, as the new Commissioner responsible, to address these tax issues. We must dry up our own tax havens, and then we can also negotiate credibly with others in the world.

name: Jonás FERNÁNDEZ
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Madam President, Commissioner, just a few minutes ago we were discussing the monetary policy of the European Central Bank. And we did not discuss what that policy should be in response to decisions from other central banks, nor did we discuss what needed to be done in the face of the exit or inflow of capital flows, or about the level of reserve we had in our boxes. And we did not discuss this because we have managed to exercise European sovereignty in the exercise of monetary policy. Something that nation states did not have in the 1990s, when the European monetary system went bankrupted, when central banks and states, in the exercise of supposed formal sovereignty, were unable to direct their monetary policy.  And that's what we have with fiscal policy today. Because today, the tax bases are more mobile than ever; today, large multinationals, large digital companies move profits from one jurisdiction to another, use transfer prices, take advantage of all the nooks and crannies of national laws so as not to pay taxes, and therefore States do not have formal sovereignty in the exercise of fiscal policy, even if they do have it in the rules. And that's what we're talking about: how to replicate our success with monetary policy in fiscal policy. And for this we need not a coordination anymore, but a minimum taxable basis — minimum, I say — in corporation tax. We need to have a common fiscality framework in capital movements. We need common rules and leadership on the part of the European Commission, controlled by this Parliament, to return to citizens the certainty that their affairs, that their problems, are led by someone, and are not in the hands of that nebula that markets are. We need an agreement in the OECD and, if there is not, we need the European Union to act to regain our fiscal sovereignty.

name: Luis GARICANO
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Madam President, Mr Gentiloni, I am going to give you some numbers which you are going to find difficult to believe: last year Apple paid four million euros in Spain for corporation tax, with revenues of EUR 394 million; Facebook paid 864,000 euros and now listens: Netflix, Mr Gentiloni, Netflix paid, ladies and gentlemen, 3,146 euros of corporation tax — three thousand. I live in a building of 24 houses; probably what Netflix enters in my building would have been enough to pay all corporation tax in Spain.  Unfortunately, they are not isolated cases, rather on the contrary, they are examples of how large multinationals avoid paying taxes in european Union countries. How, Mr Gentiloni, are we going to ask our citizens and small businesses to pay their taxes, if we allow those who earn the most not to comply? How are we going to fund our welfare states, if those who make the most money do not contribute to keeping it proportionate? How can we defend the free market, if the rules are not the same for everyone? This, ladies and gentlemen, is one of the biggest challenges facing the European Union. Our citizens look at us and expect us to find a just solution. We cannot ignore that globalization and digitization have changed the world. However, as Mr Ferber said, we continue to face the challenges of the 21st century with 19th-century rules. We can't wait any longer. Taxation must adapt to this new reality. The Resolution seeks to set rules for collection to be much more linked to revenue generation, so that there is fair competition in these markets, between companies and between States. This initiative should be adopted globally. A separate country cannot do anything to combat tax avoidance, carried out on a large scale by certain multinationals. That is why we need to cooperate and for cooperation to go beyond the European Union. And, as Mrs Tinagli said, it is not just a question of talking about the taxation of digital companies. This is happening far beyond, in all these multinationals. That is why our first objective is to achieve a comprehensive solution within the OECD framework. We believe it is the right forum, but, as you said, Commissioner - and I thank you for your commitment here to us - if the OECD at the end of 2020 is unable to act, we must act here. And I assure you of our commitment to that performance. We are going to try to make sure that, if the OECD does not act, the European Union will at least end this very unfair situation. The resolution is essential because it allows the European Union to have a unique voice in this debate and sends a very clear message that we are in favour of tax justice. This resolution makes it clear that we will not accept that the self-employed and small businesses pay more taxes than large multinationals, that we want a free market in which everyone competes with the same rules and that we will defend our welfare state and the resources that are necessary to sustain it.

name: Sven GIEGOLD
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her For more than 20 years, since my time at university, I have been fighting for tax justice internationally, for rules of globalisation with minimum tax rates, with tax transparency, so that the losers of globalisation do not pay higher taxes than the winners, but so that we have fair market conditions within the European Union, but also internationally. In this respect, I am annoyed when I see the European Commission's figures that, despite all the efforts made to achieve international tax cooperation in Europe and internationally, the effective corporate tax rate fell below 20% for the first time last year and the penultimate year. And we all know that these low tax rates do not come from the fact that small businesses no longer pay taxes, but that it is mainly large transnationally organised companies that manage to get a lean foothold here. We must not underestimate the destructive effects of this tax inequality. This damages the idea of a social market economy, which has the core idea that everyone in a market is subject to equally similar rules, so that there is fair competition. It also damages the idea of the European internal market, because a European internal market, in which in some countries no company taxes are levied and in others decent, cannot guarantee fair competition. This is a problem that is based on the legitimacy of our European economic cooperation. Let us be honest: the citizens have long believed that we are overwhelmed with these problems. We have been talking about this for decades and we are not getting to grips with the problem, and that is due to the legitimacy of democratic institutions, including the European Commission, the Council, but also of Parliament, even though the European Parliament has always made it clear the loudest that we want a different policy here. We should therefore be honest and say what we have achieved: we have managed to restrict banking secrecy internationally, so that at least private individuals can no longer easily manage the money they have earned elsewhere in Switzerland. But we haven't made it for companies. In the case of companies, we still see millions of letterbox companies where there is no economic substance and yet no taxes are paid. It is good that this is now being negotiated at OECD level, but it is not enough to take further small steps here. What we have decided under the Juncker Commission – the Anti-Tax Avoidance Directive I and II within the global scope of the BEPS agreement – has so many loopholes that it is simply worth the paper on which it is printed. Property purchases are still structured in such a way that profits are simply drawn into zero-tax countries and then our fine rules are undermined against the interest rate barrier. That is why it is so important that we finally establish common minimum tax rates that clearly state where there is a downward limit. It is sad that Christian Democrats – and I have to say some Liberals too – still have problems in clearly committing themselves to these minimum tax rates. And so do we need tax transparency. The Austrian Parliament has just lifted the opposition of the Christian Democrats there. Now is the time for the Council to finally implement the proposals and adopt country-by-country tax transparency.

name: Gunnar BECK
text: On behalf of the ID Group, I would like to make a i-see of the Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Complaints about under-tax revenues and tax dumping are – not always wrongly – political constant burners.  The European Parliament therefore seeks a global tax policy with a UN tax authority. In addition, Parliament is calling for more fiscal integration, a digital tax and the abandonment of the unanimity principle on taxes. The intention is clear: firstly, new supranational competences and authorities are being created here, and national and democratic institutions are being weakened. This is a familiar pattern, because fewer and fewer decisions are taken democratically. On the other hand, the so-called independent institutions, such as the ECB and the courts – will, in plain language, shape the irresponsible institutions that shape economic and migration policies untroubled by the electorate.  Secondly, we do not want any further breaches of EU law. EU tax laws require unanimity. It is precisely for this reason that Parliament is calling for the suspension of justice and for the unanimity of Article 113 of the Treaties to be disregarded as far as possible. Thirdly, the EU already has the highest government rate and the highest taxes on consumption, persons and companies in the OECD. These taxes are used for bank bailouts and illegal immigration. Germany alone pays more than 60 billion annually for illegal immigrants and more than 100 billion for the euro. Ladies and gentlemen, come to your senses. The citizens want more democracy and the rule of law, no more compulsory levies, world rescue fantasies and a currency that cannot stand.

name: Bogdan RZOŃCA
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab We assume that we all agree that practices of tax evasion, aggressive tax planning and tax avoidance are unacceptable. The actions of the G20 group of countries at the level of the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development are right, but it is important to reach an international consensus that is acceptable to as many countries as possible. The changes taking place will have a very large impact on the functioning of the economy – especially developed countries – in the coming years. Simple, robust and in-depth analysis is needed.  Unfortunately, I have the impression that Parliament's resolution is inconsistent. For example, it welcomes the so-called second pillar, stressing that its advantage is the taxation of value or economic activity in the country where it takes place – and that is what we would all like – but that it is in fact quite the opposite. After all, income inclusion roles will impose taxes on companies for the creation of goods or goods by a foreign subsidiary simply because the subsidiary pays lower taxes in the country where it operates. I believe that without appropriate integration, if only because of the state aid currently under discussion in the European Union, new solutions can affect the effectiveness of the agreement and set it in the interests of several countries, and then there will be no consensus that responds to the new challenges and problems of all the parties involved.

name: José GUSMÃO
text: gue/NGL Group. – Madam President, we see this text as an effort to combat the race to the bottom in the taxation of large multinational companies. This race to the fund has resulted in a huge loss of tax revenue which is then borne, in part, by the other taxpayers, particularly those who live off their work, but also by the degradation of public services and public investment policies in the Member States. But it is also a violation of the principle of the fair relationship between Member States, because there are States—Member States that draw strategies to expropriate other States—Members of the tax revenue due to them. And it is finally, now and here, in an institution where so much is discussed the undistorted competition, the level playing field, a violation of the principle of undistorted competition, not only between companies from different tax jurisdictions, but also between companies that have the ability to evade taxes using these instruments and companies that do not have that capacity. On our part, it is a distinction that has not been clarified in this text that when we discuss minimum taxation at international level, we obviously have to talk about effective taxation, because if we are not just continuing the game of tax evasion with new rules. And one thing, at least, we can say that it has become clear, that the proponents of this resolution argue that the European Union should take the initiative at this level and therefore will not take refuge in the usual excuses that yes, it is a fair fight, but it will only be possible when all the offshores in the world agree.

name: Lefteris NIKOLAOU-ALAVANOS
text: Madam President, 'fair taxation' is part of the fierce debate over the imposition of taxes on monopolistic groups of third countries competing with European Union companies, they are trade wars to control sectors of the economy with high profitability, such as the digital economy, energy, so-called 'green investments'. Talking here today about 'fair taxation' is a bad joke, since state budgets, which are controlled and ratified by the Commission, are a division of the prey of groups at the expense of workers' incomes.  Thus, in Greece with the budget of the government of New Democracy, employees and small professionals contribute to the tax revenues of the state by 93% while businesses by 7%. At the same time, the taxation of economic groups is reduced from 28% to 24%, while the taxation of dividends – the net profits of entrepreneurs – is doubled to 5%, while the bleeding of popular families continues. All kinds of engravings are imposed on the people's families while relief is given to industrialists with free electricity, which is very expensive for the people, with duty-free oil to shipowners, while poor farmers are taxed.  This is the new normality evangelised by the current government and implemented by the previous government. Workers and the working classes must claim substantial taxation of capital gains, abolition of tax exemptions, tax-free threshold covering the needs of the popular family, abolition of high, very unfair, indirect taxes.

name: Enikő GYŐRI
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support Indeed, it is time for digital companies to play their part. It is untenable that companies such as Google, Facebook, Netflix, etc. do not or barely pay tax when they make very serious revenue. We are on the right track in seeking an international solution to their taxation, in a framework wider than the Union. Indeed, the OECD is an excellent platform for this, which has put forward a two-pillar proposal. I can fully identify with the first one, which would give more taxing rights than at present to the State where the companies' customers are located. On the other proposal, which would introduce a minimum tax, however, I have a serious problem. As far as I know, no impact assessment has been carried out in this respect, so there is no answer as to whether, if OECD countries introduce that minimum tax, businesses in these countries will not transfer their headquarters outside the OECD. Undertakings are quite right to optimise their economic activity and there are fears that they will go where they have to bear less of a burden. Such a measure would therefore impair our economic environment, i.e. our own competitiveness, and fatten third countries, especially tax havens. Moreover, in addition to the increased tax obligations, we would also impose heavy administrative burdens on businesses, so this is the wrong direction. The OECD should first carry out an impact assessment and then formulate a new proposal.  Finally, one final note. Unfortunately, the text of the decision included the need to move towards a majority vote and higher harmonisation in tax policy within the Union. This, as I said earlier, would reduce the possibility of fair competition in an international context, even within the Union, and would result in companies going outside the Union. We can't afford that. The competitiveness of the Union must not be embated, which is why I ask you not to be enemies of ourselves.

name: Paul TANG
text: – Mr President, the world's largest companies, tech giants such as Facebook and Google, make many billions of profits and pay hardly any tax. It is therefore logical that the French Government, the Labour Party and others at home want to introduce a digital services tax, so that these companies too will contribute fairly. Trump and his kleptocrats, however, are threatening trade sanctions. This is a rude erosion of sovereignty and a strong attack on the OECD international negotiations to fundamentally reform the income tax. And that reform is sorely needed. The current income tax system is completely dated by globalisation and digitisation, and countries seem to have no choice but to charge even lower rates and even less income tax. We must resist american pressure and ensure that, if the negotiations fail, Europe itself is going to tax large companies. The proposals are there. However, as long as the negotiations are ongoing, Europe must act with a moratorium on income tax. If Paris, The Hague and Berlin join negotiations to curb tax dumping and, in the meantime, want to reduce the income tax at home, that is no different than hypocritical. That's not a pass.

name: Dragoș PÎSLARU
text: – Madam President, I will speak in Romanian. Commissioner Gentiloni, Madam President and Rapporteur Tinagli, is indeed an extremely important discussion that we are having today. I would like to put the issue perhaps a little differently than it has been put up so far, but coming to the same conclusion, which is that this resolution must be supported. What we are discussing in this house at this hour of the evening is not to treat multinationals as enemies of peoples. It is not about launching a war against multinational companies. There is, however, a growing perception at both European and OECD level that there are indeed significant amounts of tax revenue that are lost because of its behaviour in moving profits from one country to another. Obviously, there is the opinion of civil society and the population in several countries, in the OECD and especially in the European Union, which are becoming increasingly vocal on this subject in view of the problem. What we need to emphasise, however, and it is very important, is that here we have an obvious problem of ethics and behaviour of multinational firms, but we also have a problem of competition and lack of coordination between Member States. After all, multinationals use this framework that we have and that is not effective.  At the same time, it is a problem at the level of each Member State as regards the quality of the tax administration and the competence that that tax administration has to be able to have a unitary regime. The two proposals, the two pillars - fairer allocation of tax rights and, respectively, a global proposal to avoid tax erosion by setting a minimum tax - only work within a multilateral framework and the European Union can indeed set an example. I repeat, it is not a question of going to war in order to tax multinationals more, it is about finding fiscal fairness, a regime whereby we can ensure that small and medium-sized enterprises are not disadvantaged and, at the same time, avoid this race of differentiated taxation and different administration between Member States. I think it is an important moment for Parliament to give a positive signal in this direction, obviously not forgetting, but, what is already included in the proposal, that we are talking about simplicity, predictability and a way to develop business, not to stop them.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: – Madam President, we very much welcome this debate and the resolution that this Parliament will adopt this week. It is important that the EU plays a key role in the global debate on how to solve the tax challenges created by digitalisation and globalisation. We must ensure that the digital giants pay a fair share of the taxes, and that is not the case today. However, this proposal goes far beyond this and has the potential to update corporate tax rules and make them fit for the 21st century. We cannot govern economic relations in globalisation with the rules that we have from the 20th century. Today, transfers between subsidiaries of the same companies are taxed as if they were transfers between two independent companies. This is today at the origin of the sophisticated schemes used by multinationals for tax avoidance. One of the solutions, highly accepted among the economics and academic community, is to tax companies as global entities. The OECD has started to recognise that, as did the Commission almost ten years ago with the first proposal for a common consolidated corporate tax base. The first proposal was blocked, as was the second one of 2016. We are still waiting for news from the Council on that. We need international negotiations to reach a deal by the end of 2020, Commissioner. All EU Member States should set aside their differences and speak with one single voice. We need an ambitious deal, not the lowest common denominator – a deal which ensures that companies are taxed where they have the economic activity, meaning where they make sales, have employees and assets, where they have their clients and where they sign online contracts. The expectations of citizens for fairer taxation of multinationals is really high, and a failure of those will further create frustrations, damaging the reputation of our taxation regimes. That is why we call for joint efforts in order to make those international negotiations successful.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: – Madam President, as other speakers have mentioned, there are many positive elements of the OECD’s proposals, not least of which is the fact that that organisation is finally recognising that taxing rights need to go beyond the failed ‘arm’s length’ principle. But there have also been serious criticisms of the proposals, including from developing countries, who are excluded from much of the process, and analysis from tax justice campaigners has found that the OECD approach may actually lower the profits booked in tax havens by just 5%. The biggest problem here – the elephant in the room, so to speak – is the current US position, which puts the project for real reform on very shaky ground. The two pillars of this proposal, if agreed on in the future, will represent a fundamental shift in the global tax system towards a much fairer and more sustainable system. I’ve been warning my own government for years that it needs to end its dangerous addiction to corporate tax avoidance by Silicon Valley-based companies. Last year in Ireland, 45% of all corporate tax revenue came from just 10 multinational companies. The Member States that have encouraged tax avoidance and benefited from it are in for a rude awakening. They need nothing less than a new industrial strategy. So it’s well past time for people to get real, realise that a major shake-up of this unfair system is inevitable and start preparing for it now before the shock hits, knowing, as we do, that that shock will hit ordinary families and workers hardest of all.

name: Pilar del CASTILLO VERA
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, digital technologies, today have ceased to be an actor in itself to become the foundation of all innovative and competitive economic sectors. This is the case – an easy observation of reality is enough – from energy to financial services, from the manufacturing industry to transport, from agriculture to tourism, and much more. In this context, tax regulations such as the current one, which was conceived with business models with a physical presence in mind, are far removed from reality. Now there are many digital companies that have customers and generate value—as is well known—economic value, in countries where they are not present. But in addition, many of these earn their income from intangible assets. In turn, in the face of fiscal systems whose fundamentals are based on economies at the beginning of the last century, today we live in a global world that requires the use of a global prism.  In short, it is urgent to adapt competition rules; in this case we are talking about tax legislation, tax legislation, but it is not going to be the only time that we talk about one aspect of the principles of competition, because there are many other aspects that are linked to the same situation of digitization and globalization, and we will have the opportunity, sure, to discuss them throughout this legislature. Now we're talking about tax rules. The OECD is leading the debate and the European Union needs to lose one thing that is fundamental, which is the pulse of leadership. The pulse of leadership must be held by the Commission, successive presidencies of the Council, and that is what this Parliament and the Citizens of Europe expect.

name: Aurore LALUCQ
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, we have all heard about the various tax scandals of recent years: the LuxLeaks, the Panama Papers, and so on. What these scandals have in common is that multinationals are playing with the differences between our tax systems, that we have made only small progress in recent years on tax matters at European level , which is an understatement - and that there has been very important tax and, ultimately, social competition. I heard a colleague say earlier that we should not see multinationals as enemies. It is not a question of seeing them as enemies, it is just a matter of saying that they too must contribute in a fair proportion to the effort of our societies to finance our infrastructure, our social systems, etc. At European level, we lose $1 trillion every year because of this tax optimisation, this tax evasion. That $1 trillion would be more than useful to us to fund something called the ecological transition, which is a real emergency. That is why, among other things, the OECD has launched this BEPS 2.0, which aims to do two very simple things, struck by common sense. The first is to ensure that companies pay their taxes where they make their profits. And the second is that a minimum tax rate be set globally. The problem is Donald Trump and the fact that he will oppose this project which, however, would do us all good. That is why a large majority of parliamentarians are calling for the Commission to ensure that this project is implemented at European level.

name: Henrike HAHN
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which Tax avoidance and the fact that it can exist at all is simply a scandal. So many people in Europe take on the responsibility of generating taxpayers' money every day: on the conveyor belt, in the office, in a hospital, everywhere. This is a precious lifetime that people make available responsibly for the common good.  Responsibility must also apply to large international corporations. Many large companies do not pay the taxes required by law and use the tax loopholes. But this must also be said quite honestly: why do these tax loopholes exist in the first place? It is also up to us in politics to close them down. We need a new way of taxing the profits of multinational companies fairly and not just sharing the tax burden on small shoulders. Europe is missing billions of euros as a result of tax evasion, and that is exactly what we need to change. This is also the task of a German Presidency in 2020 to work to ensure that the EU takes great steps forward here. We now have the opportunity to bring corporate taxation up to the level of the 21st century. We now need positive joint changes instead of disputes, solo actions or sanctions.  We need great answers to big questions, especially together with the United States. We need an effective minimum tax rate in the EU and we need an agreement by the end of 2020 in the OECD negotiations. If we do not succeed in this, then the EU should go ahead and come up with a proposal on EU legislation for fair taxation of the digitised economy, for tax justice, in which tax responsibility is shared fairly on many shoulders, so that with this money we can make Europe more ecological and social. Because that is how social justice works, and that is only possible with tax justice.

name: João FERREIRA
text: – Madam President, according to existing estimates, multinationals are fleeing annually with more than US$500 billion that was owed to states in corporate tax taxation. Five hundred billion dollars that could and should be used by states in the exercise of their social functions and to relieve taxes on those who work. An inseparable reality of neoliberal policies, the free movement of capital, relocations, privatisations, the weakening of public administrations.  The proposals adopted here on the common corporate tax base and its consolidation leave several of these multinationals untouched. An effective list of tax havens would allow states to hold backs at source when there are suspicions of relocating profits to more fiscally attractive jurisdictions. This list was rejected by the Council.  It is very much what can and must be done to combat tax fraud, evasion and avoidance. Combat that involves not only, not necessarily, fiscal harmonisation and which must scrupulously respect the sovereignty of states in this area.

name: Barbara THALER
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. The market has never waited for the administration to have the right framework conditions for its developments. And that is what always presents us with challenges. This fact opens up loopholes in the law which allow companies operating internationally and also digitally to still gain further advantages because of their size and dominance. At the same time, small and medium-sized enterprises bear the full tax burden, which is unfair for the location. I myself have been an entrepreneur for twelve years and can therefore feel the situation very well. This resolution is an important input for the ONgoing OECD conciliation. One thing cannot be stressed often enough in this context: we must move away from this outdated notion of a sole physical permanent establishment and fiscal framework in such a way that transactions are taxed where they are made. Because one thing is quite clear: our economy will certainly not become less digital in the next few years. That is why I am pleased with Parliament's initiative and will be very happy to support the resolution.

name: Marek BELKA
text: – Madam President, they say that only two things in life are certain: taxes and death. Scandals such as the Panama Paper or LuxLeaks have shown that only the latter is certain. The so-called BEPS 2.0 is a step in the right direction. While taking it easy on start-ups and small companies, it is not a surprise that digital groups such as Facebook or Google will be mostly affected by the actions proposed by the OECD. However, it is improper for the US to perceive the two Pillars as an attack on the United States.  We need to act fast, adopt both of them at the same time, and react together on the international level. For this to happen, we need the US to understand that taxes should be paid where the value is created, not avoided, nor evaded. But in the EU our usual suspects also need to act with the EU core. We need to speak with one voice to influence the international negotiations. If the consultations on the international level do not succeed by the end of 2020, we in Parliament call for, as promised by Ms von der Leyen, an EU solution to tackle this phenomenon.

name: Evelyn REGNER
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. If we do it properly, then with BEPS 2.0 we will finally bring our tax law into the 21st century. And that's damn important! Taxes are an investment in the general public: children, schools, infrastructure. Companies should be proud to make profits and thus also to pay their share to the general public in the form of taxes. Taxes must be paid where the profits are generated. So basta! Facebook, Google and Co. must finally make their fair contribution, because the money is missing in our treasuries. Facebook, for example, does not pay taxes in Austria despite huge advertising revenues. While the traditional corporations from the Voest to everyone else, or many others, make a good contribution. This is unfair, it is harmful, and it must finally stop. One thing is clear: for BEPS 2.0 to work, we need transparency. We need to know where corporations pay their taxes and where they do not. Even if we have had a small step backwards, we must not give up on getting the finance ministers to finally end their blockade of Public CBCR accordingly. Austria has finally voted in favour of a motion by the Social Democrats in the National Council to put an end to this blockade that the Austrian Government had. And so I would call on the next Presidency, for the Croats, to put this issue back on the agenda. Finland has made a valuable contribution to this. Moreover, we in the European Parliament must be ambitious, that is to say, a minimum tax rate of 18%. Only in this way can we finally put an end to dumping downwards.

name: Margarida MARQUES
text: – Madam President, Commissioner Gentiloni, with the blocking in the Council the path being taken in the OECD is an opportunity to respond globally to the challenges of taxation, particularly in the digital area. As for the distribution of tax rights, what may be agreed will change the tax principles in the global economy. The discussion is moving in the right direction, albeit slowly. As for global minimum taxation, the proposal for a minimum rate of taxation at the level of each jurisdiction, in particular for digital, is welcome. In the meantime, the Council is expected to move forward with proposals on the tax base of companies. But the Commission and the Member States must ensure that the negotiations of these two pillars are done together. Finally, we hope that an agreement will be reached later next year, at least in the German Presidency of the Council. This agreement will be key to ensuring greater fiscal equity and social justice in Europe and the world.

name: Tudor CIUHODARU
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, I believe that fiscal policies must be favourable to the many and if we are talking about taxation, it must be the same for all. As you, everyone who is in the room today, those at home pay taxes where they earn their income, the same must be true for multinationals. I think we are talking about taxes as a tool by which we can ensure European health, education and infrastructure, so I support and will vote with two hands on such a resolution that makes multinationals pay taxes in the country where they get their profits, and these things are valid all over Europe and ensure the development that we all need.

name: Billy KELLEHER
text: – Mr President, I will be raising grave concerns about this particular motion in many contexts, but I think one issue that I would like to bring to Parliament’s attention is in the context of the European Union acting unilaterally on further recommendations of the OECD BEPS 2.0 report – the idea that we can somehow bring about fair taxation and globalised taxation without actually having the rest of the world involved in these discussions and acting in accordance with some of the proposals that have come forward. Because we would undermine our competitiveness as a European Union. We would discourage investment into the European Union. Let us be very, very clear. The European Union is struggling in the context of its competing with the rest of the world in the digital and global economy. We have very few multinationals that have actually started in the European Union and have blossomed and grown internationally. So the idea that we can just unilaterally act without having the rest of the world – the United States and other large trading partners – involved in that process would undermine the European Union’s competitiveness and discourage multinationals from locating here and employing EU citizens.

name: Billy KELLEHER
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, we discussed this evening an issue that will, in the coming years, be crucial for our Union and also for the sustainability of the single market and of our social model, so for this reason I think that the discussion was useful.
