I just want to stress two points. One is that your support – the support of Parliament – will be crucial in the next years, absolutely crucial, if we want to ensure real reform. Secondly, the Commission is working to try to have a common position at the OECD table. We have to cooperate with the Presidency because they are formally leading in this discussion, and I think we will have a very good cooperation with the Croatian and then German Presidencies.  I will be very clear; we are fully committed to a global solution. It is not something that we are doing without real commitment, despite the difficulties in these times of all multilateral negotiations that we have to know and recognise, but we are fully committed. This doesn’t mean that we don’t have alternatives so, as I’ve said before, the task I was given by the President is to work on this global OECD solution with all our tools and commitment, and if this is not possible, to find a European way on this, and to find this way we will again need strong cooperation between Parliament and the Commission.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: A motion for a resolution has been tabled in accordance with Rule 136(5) of the Rules of Procedure. The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday, 18 December 2019. Written declarations (Article 171 OF the CRP)

name: Carmen AVRAM
text: in writing. – I very much support this oral question debate that raises the important issue of fair taxation in a digitalised and globalised economy. I welcome the intention and ambition of this European Commission to propose a European digital tax next year if the OECD talks and negotiations on a global tax fail. We know that talks are difficult and the American position on this is a tricky one. I believe that it is a question of fairness and justice to tax big companies where huge profits are generated inside the EU Member States. The EU 500 million single market is an important piece of the cake for many companies and we should remember it when addressing the issue of taxation – and, let me add, fair taxation. As in climate and other fields, I am happy that the EU takes a leading role.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the report by Luisa Regimenti on behalf of the Committee on International Trade on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and the Council on further macro-financial assistance to the Hashemite Kingdom of Jordan (COM(2019)0411 – C9-0116/2019 - 2019/0192(COD)) (A9-0045/2019).

name: Luisa REGIMENTI
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, it is an honour for me to take the floor here as rapporteur for this important dossier. I am very pleased with the response in the INTA Committee and the unanimous vote on the report I presented and in which I recommended the granting of a third macro-financial aid of EUR 500 million to the Hashemite Kingdom of Jordan. In order to arrive at this assessment, it was necessary to analyse the economic and social situation in Jordan carefully and to take note of jordan's commendable efforts to take in refugees and the fight against Islamic terrorism and to make good the previous loans contracted with the European Union on time. In fact, the evaluations carried out on the implementation of the previous macro-financial aid programmes granted to Jordan show that the funds granted, made available in the form of long-term low-interest loans, have helped to preserve the macroeconomic stability of the country and have mainly had a positive social impact. The programmes have also been implemented efficiently and in close coordination with the Jordanian authorities. In the face of weak growth and declining investment, on 11 July 2019, the Jordanian authorities requested additional funds from the European Union to meet the country's increased needs for external and budgetary funding, partly linked to the unstable conditions in the region, among which there are large numbers of Syrian refugees in Jordan. On 6 September 2019, the Commission adopted a proposal for a third aid programme up to a maximum of EUR 500 million. I believe that, given Jordan's efforts in relation to the migration crisis and the fight against terrorism, and noting the undeniable developments regarding the level of protection of human rights and democracy, this third loan represents added value for the European Union, helping a neighbourhood country of increasing geopolitical importance to manage pressing economic and social problems.  As we all sadly know, the Syrian conflict has led to negative economic repercussions in Jordan due to the disruption of regional trade, the reduction in tourism revenues, the deterioration in investor confidence and the decrease in capital inflows in the region. The pressure on Jordan's public services, particularly in the areas of health, access to essential goods and education, has been difficult to support in the country, but the commendable effort must be acknowledged in ensuring a decent reception for refugees who are mostly living in urban areas and for whom, despite the many difficulties, access to affordable public health care and the labour market is currently guaranteed. Furthermore, I believe it is important to consider Jordan's efforts in the fight against Islamic terrorism, which are priorities of the European Union and its Member States. Jordan is a strategic partner of the European Union in cooperation on trafficking in human beings and trafficking in firearms, as well as on the exchange of personal data between Europol and the competent Jordanian authorities to combat terrorism. The Kingdom of Jordan then continues to make progress in affirming democratic principles, promoting peaceful religious coexistence and supporting freedom of religion and belief, as well as making significant social and human progress on women's rights and the protection of children. Last but not least, thanks to the progressive liberalisation of each other's markets, the presence of a stable foreign partner is also a guarantee for EU companies that they have better opportunities for trade, entrepreneurship and investment in Jordan. I repeat here that it is essential to ensure that the financial assistance granted is actually aimed at encouraging the development of the country's business investment and projects. It is also necessary to ensure, with all the instruments at our disposal, adequate control of the funds on the ground, in order to ensure that the loan disbursed is used correctly and transparently. Having said that, I believe it is necessary to show the European Union's support for a country such as Jordan with this aid, and I hope that the loan can be made available as soon as possible.  Consequently, I hope that tomorrow's vote will allow financial aid to be granted to the Hashemite Kingdom of Jordan.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: Thank you, rapporteur. I just have to tell you that you have already taken one minute thirty of your closing remarks, so that you have only 20 seconds left at the end of the debate.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, let me thank the rapporteur, Ms Regimenti, and the Committee on International Trade (INTA) for the valuable work on the report, and for the spirit of cooperation. I would also like to thank the Committee on Budgets and the Committee on Foreign Affairs for their support.  It is worth recalling where Jordan is coming from. Since 2011 the Jordanian economy has been significantly affected by regional unrest, notably in neighbouring Iraq and Syria, which led to unforeseen economic shocks even if some of its structural weakness and lack of competitiveness predates 2011. This regional unrest has taken a heavy toll on growth, external receipts, and has strained public finances. The Syrian conflict has also impacted Jordan by causing a large inflow of around 1.3 million Syrians into the country. This large inflow of Syrian refugees increased pressure on Jordan’s fiscal position, public services and infrastructures.  In these difficult circumstances Jordan has so far managed to preserve macroeconomic stability, thanks to a broadly appropriate policy response and international support. With this in mind, and upon  the request of the Jordanian authorities, the Commission adopted on 6 September a proposal for a new programme of macro-financial assistance to Jordan in the amount of EUR 500 million in loans. Building on the two previous macrofinancial assistance programmes successfully implemented, the new financial assistance will help Jordan to enhance the sustainability of its debt thanks to attractive terms of the loans, as well as to promote further structural reforms necessary to strengthen growth and the resilience of the economy. The programme is part of a wider international effort to support Jordan. Of course this assistance will be conditional on a set of structural reform measures to be agreed in a memorandum of understanding, and also on the existing and successful reviews of the IMF programme. The programme is a concrete expression of the EU’s sustained commitment to supporting Jordan, which faces an adverse and complex economic situation in a region marked by a persistently challenging and volatile environment.  The European Parliament’s support for this proposal will send a clear and encouraging signal that the European Union lives up to its commitments and continues standing by Jordan and all the people living in that country.

name: David McALLISTER
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Allow me, as chairman of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, to make a few comments on this subject. We have just heard from both the rapporteur and the Commissioner – Jordan is facing enormous challenges: the growth rate is falling, public debt is increasing and the unemployment rate is rising, especially among young people. Many external circumstances have contributed to this development. As a neighbour of Syria and iraq, Jordan is directly affected by the terrible armed conflicts in the region. According to Jordanian data – Commissioner Gentiloni has just confirmed this figure – there are currently around 1.3 million – 1.3 million! - Syrians in Jordan. Despite the enormous burden on the state and society, the country's handling of this difficult situation is exemplary. That is why it is so important that we, as the European Union, agree unanimously with Jordan's request for MACRO-financial assistance of EUR 500 million. I myself will be in Jordan on 4 and 5 January. Commissioner Gentiloni, I can only agree with you that we in the European Parliament should follow the Commission's proposal in order to be able to continue to support our partner and our ally Jordan.

name: Jérémy DECERLE
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. Mr President, Commissioner, on behalf of the Renew Group, I would like to support the payment of this third macro-financial aid to Jordan. We do believe that it can help support this country in its efforts to deal with the instability created by the Syrian government in the region. On this occasion, we also recall our commitment to the European Union's neighbourhood policy, which is also essential to the stability of our territory. However, if, on the substance, our support for this request is total, we regret that it may be in the hands of a rapporteur from the far-right group Identity Democracy in the European Parliament. On behalf of the Renew Group, made up of committed and convinced Europeans, we would like to reaffirm loud and clear in this Chamber our rejection of the destructive Eurosceptic ideas conveyed by the extreme right. We also denounce the appalling lack of coherence shown by this political family in rehabilitating, on the one hand, Bashar al-Assad and, on the other, by agreeing to help those who are ultimately its main victims.

name: Thierry MARIANI
text: On behalf of the ID Group. - Mr. President, let me begin by praising the high quality of the work of our colleague, Luisa Regimenti, who presented this report earlier. She rightly points out how the Syrian conflict has disrupted a Jordanian society already exposed to significant challenges: the reception of the people from Palestine and the control of the influence of the Muslim Brotherhood, among others. Jordan is one of the most serious countries in the region, economically speaking. Its currency is preserved and the country is actively working to develop its tourism activity. Luisa Regimenti mentions, with relevance, the strong economic growth that Amman had enjoyed until then. I would add that, as a staunch defender of Eastern Christians, the King of Jordan has had an exemplary attitude towards Jordanian Christians. The country must therefore benefit from a concerted international solution for the benefit of Iraqi Christians and Mandeans, who have fled the Islamic State organization and must now find a place to rebuild their lives. This "package" of 500 million euros of loans, we will grant it to Jordan, because this country carries the burden of an international crisis that no one wants to solve. The border between Jordan and Syria has been open for months now. How can we explain why no international resettlement plan for Syrian refugees is in place?! Ladies and gentlemen, we have the opportunity to renew European policy in the Levant, to opt for a strategic policy; it is necessary and, of course, we are very much in favour of the report presented.

name: Tudor CIUHODARU
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, I am Tudor Ciuhodaru, emergency doctor in Iasi, Romania, at the "Nicolae Oblu" Emergency Clinical Hospital, and I appreciate that today the European Parliament is taking the right solution. People's health and lives must not have political colour and, if we are talking about European values, anything must be done, by anyone, regardless of political colour, for these things to be sustained. Even if the rapporteur has a certain political colour, to be honest, it is less important. The people of Jordan need this loan in order to ensure their health, in order to be able to survive and we, as the European Parliament, must show ourselves, once again, with openness to those who are truly a partner in respecting European values. I will vote with two hands on this report and I appreciate the work of the European Commission.

name: Tudor CIUHODARU
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I just wanted to underline the fact that the Council has already confirmed that it will approve the European Parliament position if Parliament adopts its position on the first reading immediately. In such a case, the process will be on track to be completed less than four months after the Commission presented the proposal. I think that such swift decision-making on a crisis instrument like macro-financial assistance is very relevant in general, and is absolutely needed for Jordan. So thank you to the rapporteur and to Parliament for this commitment.

name: Luisa REGIMENTI
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, thank you for your contributions and, in particular, I would like to thank my fellow doctor because I am a doctor too.  The importance and urgency of this dossier deserves an analysis that goes beyond the divisions between parliamentary groups. I therefore hope that the unanimous positive vote in the INTA Committee can be confirmed. I would like to stress that the validity and necessity of the vote in favour of this dossier should call on the whole House to express itself according to our conscience and to fulfil the ultimate duty of all of us members to serve the interests of the States we represent.  For these reasons, I hope that we will be able to reach a positive vote on this dossier, which deserves to be evaluated independently, leaving aside group dynamics and often unfounded prejudices that have arisen on my group.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Tuesday, 17 December 2019.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: The next item on the agenda is the one-minute speeches on important political issues (Article 172 of the CRP).

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank the European In recent years, there have been legislative changes in Ukraine that have significantly restricted the rights of minorities to use languages. The revision of Article 7 of the Education Act adopted in 2017, despite the recommendation of the Venice Commission, has not been carried out and has even begun to be implemented. In addition, on 8 December, the Venice Commission called on Ukraine to repeal the provisions of the law on the use of ukrainian language adopted in April 2019 which distinguish between Ukrainian and other languages, as the law is discriminatory. The international body called on Ukrainian lawmakers to legislate as soon as possible on the status of minorities and to involve representatives of minorities in its preparation. Since this law should have been prepared in parallel with the article on the functioning of the Ukrainian language, the implementation of the law should have been postponed until it was adopted. I trust that Kiev will recognise as soon as possible that respect for and implementation of international documents guaranteeing the protection of fundamental human and minority rights is an essential condition for its approach to the European Union.

name: Tudor CIUHODARU
text: – Mr President, Schengen is one of the most important achievements of the European Union. The Schengen system provides the highest standards on border management and Romania meets these standards, and I call on the Council not to delay and follow the European Parliament's recommendations to ensure Romania's integration into Schengen. You know, I'm not saying this, says the former President of the European Parliament, Jerzy Buzek, and you know when he's saying it? June 8, 2011. Look at you too, it has been almost ten years, and that is why I must go back home and tell the Romanians that today, in the European Parliament, I have once again asked you, Honoured Commission, your honour, to enter Schengen. We meet all the criteria and I hope that this will be done as soon as possible because Romanians also have the right to be in this European space, especially since we are all those who love these European values.

name: Phil BENNION
text: – Mr President, on 15 November, protests against the tripling of gas prices began throughout Iran, and they spread quickly. The regime engaged in a bloody suppression and completely blocked the internet on 17 November, to prevent news on the scale of the process and the scope of its brutal crackdown spreading. According to Amnesty International, over 300 people have been killed, and I’ve heard estimates from other groups that say it could even be as high as 1 500. The United Nations Human Rights Office reports that women and children are among those killed, and at least 7 000 people have been arrested. I urge the United Nations Security Council, governments and the international community to condemn these killings and the suppression and call for the release of those detained. Internet access for all needs to be completely restored, along with the human rights of those who have been detained. Iran must fulfil its obligations to international human rights law by respecting the rights of freedom of expression and peaceful assembly.

name: Nico SEMSROTT
text: – Mr President, the EU is in deep crisis and so am I. I have binge—watched this show for the past few months and I’m not amused. It’s not getting enough clicks, the engagement rate is pathetic and, in general, there is a lack of good content. I want to give you all here direct feedback. First, the storylines don’t make any sense: in one episode we are saying the EU stands for peace and in the next we are rushing to build up our military. Second, the characters are hard to follow: I don’t know any of you. Third, the message keeps getting lost.  We should take a lesson from the Eurovision Song Contest. People pay attention to naked people dancing. If ratings don’t improve, the whole thing will soon be cancelled. We need to offer our audience something worth watching. From the broken heart of Europe, I am Nico Semsrott and this is the Nico Semsrott Show with Nico Semsrott.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: May I just tell you that I would ask you to remove your headgear in future, because that is not in line with the dignity of the House.

name: Maxette PIRBAKAS
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I wanted to warn you this evening about the return of a scandal that has affected the health of millions of Europeans overseas, from the West Indies: the chlordecon affair. Article 168 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union refers to a high level of protection of human health. I ask, as a Member of Parliament for Overseas Affairs, that european Union aid be granted to help my fellow West Indians who have suffered direct or collateral damage in this chlordecocone case. The use of chlordecon is responsible for many health problems, while its effects were known to the French government authorities. However, it maintained the authorization to use chlordecon between 1972 and 1993 in Caribbean banana plantations. Colleagues, the human health of every European must be a common goal. To do this, funds must be allocated to Caribbean victims.

name: Hermann TERTSCH
text: – Mr President, I would like from here to congratulate Boris Johnson and the British people on their superb electoral victory with the Conservative Party, with which we have had the honour of sharing this group, the ECR Group. I am very sorry that you are leaving, because I believe that the British's strong vocation of freedom is more necessary than ever to reform the European Union; but I congratulate you precisely on your courage to stand up for what you think is right and never let yourself be intimidated in history.  The British elections are, for us, a great opportunity. The Commission and this whole Parliament must take a conscience test, which they did not do on 23 June 2016. Then the Union had to open a period of reflection to look into the root causes of the outcome. On the contrary, he devoted himself to disqualifying the Decision of the British. Now the whole European Union has a great opportunity to avoid being followed by other countries, which are becoming more uncomfortable in the Union, by impositions made by unelected bodies (inaudible words). It must stop harassing democratic governments with large majorities such as (inaudible words) returning to stricter subsidiarity and respect for sovereignty (inaudible words) ... (the president withdrew the floor to the speaker).

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: – Mr President, steel industry representatives have warned the European Commission several times this year that their sector is in crisis. The European Commission replied that it had taken all measures to reverse these developments. But the reality is different. Companies are reducing production, laying off employees and considering whether to continue their activities at all. Arcelor Mittal decided to suspend production in Krakow, leading to the loss of work for 1,300 people. Tata Steel has announced that it will cut 3,000 jobs in Europe and others are shuting down their furnaces, including U.S. Steel Košice, where 2,500 people will lose their jobs. And that's not all. Steel from the European Union is produced under stricter environmental and social conditions than in third countries. Although the European Union pretends to be taking action in the interests of greening, it is destroying its modern and environmentally friendly operations by increasing quotas for dirty steel from third countries. The European Commission says that it has responded well to the introduction of restrictive measures, but this is not true.  And I ask you: what will you, as the new Commission, do to help the steel industry in Europe?

name: Milan ZVER
text: – Mr President, one issue that has been raised with great concern by many MEPs in the European Parliament in the last weeks is the horrific human rights situation in Iran, following the nationwide protests which erupted on 15 November and  spread to almost 200 cities. Our concern is how the killings and mass arrests have been minimised by the regime in Iran, while there have been at least 1 500 people killed and 12 000 arrested. The main Iranian opposition, the National Council of Resistance of Iran (NCRI), has gathered the names of over 500 people killed, among them dozens of women, including four mothers and many minors such as Nikta Esfandani – look at this picture. She was 14. I am calling on the European Union and the United Nations to despatch a fact-finding mission to Iran as soon as possible.

name: Ibán GARCÍA DEL BLANCO
text: – Mr President, in Europe it is estimated that around 410 000 people live on the street. Besides, it's not a passing situation. It is estimated that, in my country, for example, almost 50% have been in this situation for more than three years, and living on the street kills, ladies and gentlemen. There is no human situation of greater vulnerability, there is no situation that further attacks even personal dignity and against the same concept that we have of citizenship in Europe than living on the street, than homelessness. We see it even, ladies and gentlemen, if we want to, at the European Parliament's own doors in Brussels, and that should, in truth, embarrass and embarrass us.  Those of us here have an obligation to act in this situation, not only because Agenda 2030 says so or the European social pillar has said so, but because we have tools at our disposal. A member country like Finland is showing that there are more efficient and more effective ways to act, and we can import that model. We can act directly, we can make recommendations to the member countries themselves, which are also heard by regional or local authorities. We can and must act.

name: Jane BROPHY
text: – Mr President, this may be my last opportunity to speak here on behalf of the north-west of England, and I want to say thank you to the EU for standing up for us when no one else did. You provided a safety net for us when our government didn’t. You gave us power and freedom to shape our own lives. You connected us to the world and expanded our horizons. You invested in us, giving us trams, buses and trains, doctors and nurses, culture, arts and peace. You pushed for cleaner air. You gave us tougher carbon targets to try and protect us from dangerous climate change. You stand up for us on the global stage. And most critically of all, when the north-west was starved of opportunity you believed in us.  We are grateful. We know the good that you do. This is not the end. The north-west of England is still best served by living in an open, tolerant country, working with our neighbours and the EU, and it breaks my heart that we’re walking away from all of this.

name: Francisco GUERREIRO
text: – Mr President, on 10 December Isabel Lourenço, a human rights activist, was expelled from the occupied territories of Western Sahara by the authorities of the Kingdom of Morocco. Isabel, a Portuguese citizen, and a European citizen, respected all the requirements of Moroccan law for entry into the country. He had a valid passport, travel permit, information about the hotel he was staying at and a return plane ticket to Las Palmas. What he would want with his visit was clear: to know the reality of gdeim Izik's political prisoners. However, at El Aaiún airport, Isabel Lourenço was classified as persona non grata who was trying to attack Morocco's sovereignty. The activist saw her computer and mobile phones forbade, having been prevented from making any calls and sent, against her own will, to Agadir via a taxi. I conclude by saying that the kingdom of Morocco's continued repression of activists and the Sahrawi people, especially in Western Sahara, must end and the European Commission must take a firm stand in the defence of human rights in this country.

name: Christine ANDERSON
text: – Herr Präsident! Weihnachten steht vor der Tür, das schönste Fest des Jahres. Ich wollte daher die Gelegenheit nutzen, um allen ein gesegnetes Weihnachtsfest zu wünschen und ein gesundes, glückliches und erfolgreiches neues Jahr. But this year, my very special Christmas greetings go out to the British people. Thank you for having shown us a way out of this bureaucratic EU tyranny, and here it goes (sings): ‘I wish you a Merry Brexit, I wish you a Merry Brexit, I wish you a Merry Brexit, may you finally be free’. I applaud the British people.

name: Radan KANEV
text: – Mr President, the question before us is can there be a fair transition where there is no fairness? Today the town of Pernik in Bulgaria is without water, 130 thousand people expect Christmas with several hours of undringable water per day, over half a billion was spent on dams in Bulgaria, and it turned out that drinking water, which is the right of every European citizen, is used unchecked for industrial purposes. This is a serious example of political corruption, this is actually the price of political corruption. And a few days ago, the Chief Prosecutor, whose seven-year term does not have a single high-level corruption charge, was elected chairman of the anti-corruption commission in Bulgaria, and his former deputy was elected Attorney General. The European Union is preparing to invest hundreds of billions in new environmental projects. The question is can the European Commission and the EPPO ensure their fair spending?

name: César LUENA
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in the region of Murcia, in Spain, in the Mar Menor, in a saltwater lagoon, three tonnes of dead fish appeared in mid-October. This is climate change, for those who deny it. They said it was the cold drop, but then it has been shown not to. The causes are intensive agricultural use, speculation and the lack of regulation of conservative governments for 40 years. And, look, now you need to restore the wetland of the lagoon, control the spills and clean the water with green filters. And for this we Spanish Socialists come here, to ask the European Commission for support to continue to increase nature-based solutions, to investigate this particular case and also to help , because they need it - the fishermen of the Mar Menor, in the Murcia region of Spain.

name: Billy KELLEHER
text: – Mr President, when the United Kingdom leaves the European Union, the rest of the remaining countries will have no university in the top 30 worldwide. So, from the point of view of European Union investment in Horizon Europe, we need to ensure that there’s a concentrated effort across the European Union from the Commission and the Council – and the Member States – to invest in research, innovation, technology and digitisation.  We are talking about transitioning to a carbon neutral economy yet we don’t have the capacities because we don’t have the capacity in our universities and we don’t have the graduates that are flowing from that. It is a major inhibitor on growth in the eurozone area and the broader European Union. So we have to stimulate investment, encourage universities to take up grant aid from Horizon Europe and to ensure that Member States – which education is the competency of – have the capacity to invest in third level colleges in their own areas. This is something we’re denying them at the moment because of the Stability and Growth Pact. We need to start investing in research and innovation and that starts in our universities.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: Mr President, the European Council's repeated wishful talks do not at all stem Turkey's aggression and violations of the sovereign rights of neighbouring states, as the arbitrary Turkey-Libya pact shows. On the contrary, the ongoing refugee bazaar, the sale of arms by Germany and other states to Turkey, the assurances of a strategic partner of the European Union, all break it down. Given respectively the attitude of the United States, NATO and the UN to the role of "Pontius Pilate", it is out of reality and dangerous the cultivated complacency by the government of New Democracy and by SYRIZA, much more so the government climate of euphoria. Euro-Atlantic methods for co-management in the Aegean and Eastern Mediterranean will exacerbate the contradictions and further complicate the situation. Popular interests are at odds with those of groups. The answer is to intensify the popular struggle against foreign bases, the urban classes and imperialist associations, so that the peoples can live in peace with their own authority, with respect for sovereign rights.

name: Sunčana GLAVAK
text: – Mr President, allow me to make a brief review of the European Green Deal and its role in shaping a different Europe. And will continue in Croatian. The Green Deal will be crucial for the future of Europe and the world. We are witnessing great changes in the world. Fires, sea and ocean levels are rising year after year and are menaing numerous islands and cities. Last month, split, the second largest city in Croatia, measured the highest sea level since 1955. Croatia faced one of the largest fires in history in two years, and the floods in 60 seconds took homes and streets before our eyes. This is what I witnessed.  The fight against climate change was launched on one of croatia's 1,244 islands, the island of Zlarin. They will no longer use single-use plastics and have introduced such a rule even before the European Commission and the decision to ban it. The Green Deal is an opportunity to create new jobs, improve quality of life and grow economically.  I will conclude with the words of Ban Ki-moon: "We are the last generation that can take steps to avoid the worst impact of climate change. Future generations will not forgive us if we fail to maintain our moral and historical responsibilities."

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: – Mr President, last week the first Euro-Latin American Parliamentary Assembly we held during this term was held in Panama, Panama City, which I was also fortunate and privileged to co-chair. During this very relevant but particularly relevant meeting now that the region is in serious turbulence, we Europeans wanted to send a clear message, supporting bilateral relations, a framework, already established, of strategic partnership that we want to continue and work for over the next five years, and with recipes for the problems that the region is living in. What are the recipes? Institutionality and the fight against inequality. The need to have strong institutions that digest citizens' demands, while making social cohesion the cement for our democracy. At the same time, Members from both regions send a clear message: we want the European Union-CELAC summits to return and the first-level summits between prime ministers and presidents from both regions to return.

name: Peter POLLÁK
text: – Mr President, if Hitler had won the war, I would not have been here today. There are also Members sitting in this Chamber who admire Hitler's ideology about supremacy. There are people sitting in this room who divide us according to how we look, not the way we act. They divide us according to prejudice and not by deeds. During the Second World War, tens of millions of innocents died because of a pernicious ideology, also because many Europeans believed it. In my country, Slovakia, fascists used to go in military shoes and uniforms a few years ago. Today they were swapped for half-drowns and expensive suits. They don't march down the street, they're in parliament. They shamelessly attach the cross of Jesus Christ to their expensive saups. They preach hatred and even abuse the Christian faith for it, just to make people like it. But God has nothing to do with hatred. The extremists are gaining strength with each and every other election. Especially among the young. We cannot repeat the mistakes of our ancestors, who were silent during the onset of fascism. We'll learn from history. No one is sure that fascism does not concern him. No one is sure that he himself will not end up on the list of victims of fascism.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, it is many times that we have had to come to this House to denounce the abusive and discriminatory attitude and practices on the part of a low-cost airline by Ryanair. This time it has occurred as a result of preventing a young woman, Bethlehem Hueso, a Valencian woman like me, from flying, who is prevented by a degenerative disease and who needs to move in an electric chair because her arms prevent her from moving the manual chair. But Ryanair has considered that he had no right to fly, that he had no right to go with his wheelchair and has left it on the ground. The wheelchair is your arms and legs and without them you cannot exercise the right to mobility that pleases you. That is why I wonder how much more has to pass, how much more Ryanair has to infringe European labour law — how it is using its workers — and how much more it has to denigrate its passengers in order for this Commission to take action. I ask you, Commissioner, please take interest. Make it the last case.

name: Susanna CECCARDI
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the system of traffic light labels, otherwise known as Nutri-Score, is spreading throughout Europe, classifying those with low sugars, low fats as healthy and healthy products, and perhaps classifying our Parmesan cheese, Tuscan ham or even extra virgin olive oil as unsanurable products. In fact, this is a misleading system for the consumer, who tries to indoctrinate him and tries to steer him towards products that are not said to be healthy overall.  But did our girls need the Nutri-Score or traffic light label to know how much olive oil they had to put in the soup? They knew the impeccable qualities of the Mediterranean diet and therefore all the made in Italy products that make up this diet. We the only label that we will always defend here will be only made in Italy.

name: Matthew PATTEN
text: – Mr President, unlike the Labour and Liberal Democrat parties, the EU should not hide its head in the sand about the British general election. This is not the result of stupid British voters or the media or fascist racists or climate deniers. It’s not because of Vladimir Putin or Donald Trump or little green men from Mars. It’s because at every step the EU has chosen to give less when it could have offered more. Instead of being generous to David Cameron, Theresa May or Margaret Thatcher, John Major, or even Tony Blair, it has chosen to make life difficult, and the result is that the fifth largest economy on the planet, a Permanent Member of the UN Security Council, a founding Member of the Council of Europe, is leaving. German, French and Scandinavian taxpayers will now have to pay more. Many EU Members will get much less. European influence in the world will decline.  Mr Johnson looks forward to negotiating a fantastic deal with the EU, but the EU again wants to offer less, restricting trade and self-determination. Please learn the lessons of Brexit. Our nations and citizens have always achieved most when we’ve embraced a free-market free-trading culture. So be generous, do a fantastic deal, support my constituents’ democratic wishes in the East Midlands, and in return the UK will support our European friends to be greener, safer, richer and happier.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: For the sake of order, I would like to say that you know that the withdrawal procedure has three parts, namely the divorce agreement, the transitional arrangements and the negotiations on the further relationship, and we are in discussion in all three areas.

name: Irena JOVEVA
text: – Mr President, shame at the heart of Europe. Of course, you cannot know what I mean specifically, because we have them, these shames, quite, unfortunately.  Well, in this case, I'm talking about Vučjak. So this refugee migrant camp in Bosnia and Herzegovina was named in public, and it was indeed a disgrace. Therefore, we can be satisfied that the people from there were transferred from there a few days ago and that this camp was closed down. It was necessary to get along. But did this end the migrant refugee crisis as such? Not.  We need an agreement, a common agreement, a common single migration and asylum policy in parallel with the bailout, but a real resolution, of these problems in the countries of origin. For? Because if this mandate ends again without this, then we will be the biggest embarrassment at the heart of Europe.

name: Tomislav SOKOL
text: – Dear Chairman, cancer is today one of the biggest public health problems in the European Union and even in the world.  Almost two million people die of cancer annually in Europe, namely the European Union, and as many as 40% of these deaths, unfortunately, could have been prevented if adequate measures had been taken. On the other hand, we know that healthcare is the primary competence of the Member States, and this is defined in Article 168 TSR. treaty on the functioning of the European Union. On the other hand, this provision must not be an excuse for the European Union to do nothing to fight cancer. Today, the European Union has many instruments, both financial and regulatory, to tackle this problem. From better implementation of the Directive on cross-border health services, through investments in scientific research related to health through horizon, to cohesion policy through which one can invest in health infrastructure and in labour capital, i.e. the health workforce. In other words, today the European Union has the instruments to fight cancer. We have a political atmosphere and will on the part of the Commission and Parliament in this and let's make an effort so that we can really make a result. Let us show that the European Union is not a bureaucratic monster but can indeed improve the lives of its citizens.

name: Cristian TERHEŞ
text: – Mr President, the Cooperation and Verification Mechanism was implemented in 2006, before Romania and Bulgaria entered the European Union. The purpose of this mechanism was conceived as a system of analysis, verification of justice in Romania and Bulgaria to ensure that these two countries, once integrated into the European Union, reach the same standard of democracy and rule of law as the other European countries.  Regrettably, however, in the case of Romania, we see that, in recent years, this Cooperation and Verification Mechanism is not only no longer technical and has been turned into a purely political report, but the report on Romania in recent years contains a number of errors that have also generated a negative reaction from the Romanian magistrates.  In addition to these factual, quantitative, qualitative errors that exist in this report, the latest written report on Romania, generated by the European Commission, denies provisions of the Romanian Constitution and the decisions of the Romanian Constitutional Court. The invitation I make to the European Commission is to re-evaluate how this report assessed justice in Romania in 2019 and rewrite it.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: That concludes this item.
